script: AddTextSmall "获得了 行星杀手 的坐标" highlight
text:
虽然全息投影没有任何变化，你没在听到那个声音再说任何话语了。

看上去，似乎驱动这一切的存在已经离开了。

你的通讯官惊讶地瞪眼看着你。其他人的表情多是掩饰不住的恐惧和疲惫的不解。
options: pk_hackStoryEnd:"星历日结尾时给我报告！解散。"

text:
他们的报告没有告知任何你预料之外的内容。

技工们被要求对$shipOrFleet的电脑系统进行一个比平常更小心的扫描。扫描结果没发现多出任何本来不该在系统里的东西 —— 至少没有平时多出来的更多。你 '谈话'  中记录的遥测信息也没能提供有用的信息。

但是在你通讯缓存中出现的航行坐标看上去确实是有效的。

script: FireAll COB_AddOptions FireBest COB_DisableOptionsIfNeeded FireAll COB_DisableIndividualOptions

id: # PK conversation with automated fleet if you have Hegemony commission and got them to leave the asteroid

text:
一个合成声音热情地回应了你："准备就绪。正在待命。无人自主操控已强制生效。"

人之领 第十四战斗群的徽标在通讯器中闪烁，从文字传输通道传来的信息和音频通道信息，叠加显示在了上面。

"准备就绪。正在待命。无人自主控制已强制生效。"
notes:
# This is the defender fleet that was in the asteroid but, using your Hegemony-commission-codes, you got them to leave it.

# also: no explicit knowledge of AI core use revealed here

options: pk_turnInPather:"我有你们要的行星杀手。"

text:
$PersonName双手合十，闭上了$hisOrHer眼睛喃喃自语，听起来像是感谢天意。

我承认，舰长，我没想到你会回来，" $heOrShe说。
options:
pk_givePKPather:安排把它交出去
pk_uselessPather:"没有密码的话，它不就是一块废铁？"
pk_whatPather:"我要你保证你不会对人们使用这个东西。"
cutCommLink:"嗯，别在意。" (切断通讯链接)

script:
AdjustRep luddic_path 10
AdjustRepActivePerson 25
AddRemoveAnyItem SPECIAL planetkiller -1
$player.turnedInPlanetkiller = true
$player.patherAgreement = true
$player.patherAgreementPermanent = true
AddPotentialContact
HA_CMD gavePKToPather
$receivedAPlanetkillerFromPlayer
text:
你与左径分子协调配合，把行星杀手移交给他们保管。

"你的行为值得赞扬，$playerSirOrMadam，你为卢德的愿景服务 —— 尽管我等的修业之径将会如此黑暗，如此扭曲。"

"你的... 合作将由那些真正忠诚的人口口相传。" $HeOrShe再次将双手合十，"愿神圣的和平降临于你，$playerName，直到末日，直到一切受到审判之时。"
"并不像你想的那样无用，" $heOrShe说。"这是一个被造物主诅咒的图腾，是异教徒害怕和崇拜的恶魔。它拥有力量 —— " $heOrShe克制住了$himOrHerself自己。你意识到了尽管$heOrShe很兴奋，但还是不要太过公开地谈论左径徒的计划。

$HeOrShe凝视了你好一会儿才开口。"你和我都很清楚，我对你撒谎简直易如反掌。毕竟借口这么多，而我又非圣贤。所以我们就别浪费时间演戏了。"

"武器可以成为一种威慑，也能成为一件凶器。你对这方面的了解应该不比我差。假如我发自内心地宣称它永远不会被使用，而且大家都相信我，那么它就不再是一种威慑。" $HeOrShe顿了顿，继续说道，"—— 那它就只能成为一件凶器了。这种情况显然对我们大家来说都更加危险，你不觉得吗？"

options: pk_turnInHegemony:"我想谈谈行星杀手武器。"

text: $PersonRank $personLastName 的脸绷紧了。"我没有时间也没有兴趣重新争论 AI 战争的历史，舰长。如果您没有其他紧急事务，那就让我们到此为止吧。"
options:
pk_turnInHegemony2:"你误会了，我找到了一台行星杀手。"
pk_turnInHegemonyAbortEarly:"哦，那就算了。"

text: 海军上将 Rao 的脸绷紧了。"我不想争论 AI 战争的历史，舰长，也不讨论某些叛变的前霸主军官及其罪行。"
options:
pk_turnInHegemony2:"你误会了，我找到了一台行星杀手。"
pk_turnInHegemonyAbortEarly:"哦，那就算了。"

text:
霸主 $post 瞪大了眼睛，$heOrShe说 "我... 我明白了。我们需要派一个技术小组来确认你的说法，并将那台武器送到安全的地方保管。"

$hisOrHer的语气里充满了了怀疑，但比起真的不相信你，听起来更像是某种微弱的希望 —— 那人希望你只是在撒谎。
options:
pk_hegFree:"当然。向有关当局提交违禁武器是每个公民的责任。"
pk_hegPay:"你不认为这样的诚实值得奖励吗？500,000 星币就可以了。"
cutCommLink:切断通讯连接

text:
海军上将 Rao 惊讶地扬起眉毛；但不知为何，他看上去也没有那么惊奇。"我明白了。做得好。我们需要派一个技术小组来确认你的说法，当然也要将那台武器送到安全的地方保管。" 

他的语气中仍然带有怀疑的意味，但可以肯定的是，你已经引起了他的注意。
options:
pk_hegFree:"当然。向有关当局提交违禁武器是每个公民的责任。"
pk_hegPay:"你不认为这样的诚实值得奖励吗？500,000 星币就可以了。"
cutCommLink:切断通讯连接

text:
"你的奉献精神和服务值得赞扬！我以个人的名义向你致敬，因你献身于霸主保护人类及其宜居环境的使命，正如那个许多年前在 Eventide 赋予霸主权力的人 —— 第一任至高霸主 Kali Molina 的愿景一样。"

你肯定 $personName 正在调整姿势记录下这段通讯。
无论如何，霸主的官僚机构运作得很顺利，也许是因为不想再出现一次像摧毁 Opis 那样的 "意外" 。一个技术团队鉴定了这台行星杀手，然后迅速将其移交给了霸主的监管机构，并为你回收大规模杀伤性武器的行为提供了报酬。

script:
AddCommodity credits 100000
AdjustRep hegemony 25
AdjustRepActivePerson 25
AddRemoveAnyItem SPECIAL planetkiller -1
$player.turnedInPlanetkiller = true
AddPotentialContact
$player.ethosOrder++
$receivedAPlanetkillerFromPlayer
text:
报酬被打到了你的账户里，这意味着你可能会参选某个服务类奖项。

有人认为，行星杀手会被藏在某个秘密武器库里。

"$playerName，你的奉献精神和服务值得赞扬！"

"作为一名现役辅助军，你已经宣誓效忠于 霸主 的事业，但我仍以个人的名义向你致敬，因你献身于 霸主 保护人类及其宜居环境的使命，正如那个许多年前在 Eventide 赋予 霸主 权力的人 —— 第一任至高霸主 Kali Molina 的愿景一样。"

$HeOrShe本人直接向你敬了个礼。

你肯定 $personName 正在调整姿势记录下这段通讯。

霸主的官僚机构运作得很顺利，也许是因为不想再出现一次像摧毁 Opis 那样的 "意外" 。

一个技术团队鉴定了这台行星杀手，然后迅速将其移交给了霸主的监管机构，并为你回收大规模杀伤性武器的行为提供了报酬。

script:
AddCommodity credits 100000
AdjustRep hegemony 25
AdjustRepActivePerson 25
AddRemoveAnyItem SPECIAL planetkiller -1
$player.turnedInPlanetkiller = true
AddPotentialContact
$player.ethosHonorable++
$player.ethosOrder++
$receivedAPlanetkillerFromPlayer
text:
除了佣金，还有一笔奖励被打进你的账户，这意味着你可能会参选某个服务类奖项。

有人认为，行星杀手会被藏在某个秘密武器库里。

"为了霸主的复兴！" $heOrShe狂喜地说。"祝你航行无阻，舰长。"

"当然，" $rank 咬牙切齿。"奖励有助于 霸主 星域内全体公民安全生活的行为...符合...政策。"

"我必须确认您的 特殊 请求，" $heOrShe着重强调了"特殊"二字，"当然，还得有上级确认。"
options:
pk_hegPay2:"当然，我等着你的答复。"
pk_hegPayNo:"这只是我一个想法。我当然会把行星杀手无偿交给你。" 
cutCommLink:切断通讯连接

text:
"当然，" $rank 咬牙切齿。"奖励有助于 霸主 星域内全体公民安全生活的行为...符合...政策。"

"我必须确认您的 特殊 请求，" $heOrShe着重强调了"特殊"二字，"当然，还得有 指挥部 确认。"
options:
pk_hegPay2:"当然，我等着你的答复。"
pk_hegPayNo:"这只是我一个想法。我当然会把行星杀手无偿交给你。" 
cutCommLink:切断通讯连接

text: "非常合理，公民。" 你的让步似乎让$himOrHer心情好了一些。$heOrShe清了清$hisOrHer的嗓子，把一些不愉快抛之脑后。

尽管$PersonRank $personName 个人似乎对你在有一份佣金的情况下还提出这样的要求感到不满，但$hisOrHer的上级似乎没有反对意见。

霸主的官僚机构运作得很顺利，也许是因为不想再出现一次像摧毁 Opis 那样的 "意外" 。

尽管$PersonRank $personName 个人似乎对你在有一份佣金的情况下还提出这样的要求感到不满，但$hisOrHer的 指挥部 似乎没有反对意见。

霸主的官僚机构运作得很顺利，也许是因为不想再出现一次像摧毁 Opis 那样的 "意外" 。

script:
AddCommodity credits 500000
AdjustRep hegemony 5
AddRemoveAnyItem SPECIAL planetkiller -1
$player.turnedInPlanetkiller = true
$player.ethosMercenary++
$receivedAPlanetkillerFromPlayer
$receivedAPlanetkillerFromPlayerMercenary
text:
霸主的技术团队证实了你持有行星杀手的说法，在星币到账时，他们就把这件武器运出了你的$shipOrFleet。

"如果所有公民都像你一样 '尽职尽责' ，$playerSirOrMadam，我很快就会花光我的部队预算。" $personName 冷淡地说。"祝好。"

options: pk_turnInArroyo1:"嘘，你想要一台行星杀手吗？"

text:
"又是这样。"他冷冷地看了你一眼，"我希望你在爬回来找我之前，没有向任何人兜售过这种曾在人之领时代造成数十亿人死亡的大规模杀伤性武器。"

他的态度直降冰点。

"对吧？"
"不，" 他说。"并且我们从来没谈过关于你卖给我大规模杀伤性武器的事。"
"你已经开过了那个玩笑。" 他说。"那一次并不好笑。"
options:
pk_turnInArroyo2:"我这次是认真的，行星杀手可是个稀罕货。我想到了你，你相当有钱。"
pk_turnInArroyo1joke:"只是想让你度过愉快的一天。"

text:
不出所料，Arroyo 对你的话感到吃惊。

"你认真的？" 他仔细打量着你。
options:
pk_turnInArroyo2:"非常认真。行星杀手非常罕见。我想到了你，因为你很有钱。"
pk_turnInArroyo1joke:"不，仅仅是一个小玩笑。"

text:
"真搞笑。"

他没笑。

"谢谢。"

他听起来并没有多么感谢你。

"好主意，$playerName。"

他抬起眼睛，什么也没有看，考虑着他的选择。如果有什么不同的话，他似乎对你的提议感到压力山大。

"我可以支付 300,000 星币，" 他最终说道。"尽管无需多言，但我需要你对此保密。你先来找我是件好事。"

他眨了眨眼。

"你是首先来找的我，对吧？"

"很好。"

他叹了口气。"300,000 星币。成交？"
options:
pk_turnInArroyo3deal:"成交。"
pk_turnInArroyoMore:"我想要更多星币。"
pk_turnInArroyoNoDeal:"不，我改变主意了。"

text:
他把脸埋在手掌里，深深地吸了一口气。

"你这个白痴，" 他叹了口气说。

"我可以再加 150,000 星币。这是我能对一件热门商品开出的最高价。"
options:
pk_turnInArroyo3dealLow:"成交。"
pk_turnInArroyoNoDeal:"不，我改主意了。

text: "太糟糕了，" 他说。"你只能找其他人来购买你那台，害死过数十亿人的 人之领 时代大规模杀伤性武器了。"
options:
pk_turnInArroyo3deal:"我改主意了。300,000 星币是个好价钱。"
pk_turnInArroyoNoDeal2:"正有此意。"

text: "祝你好运，希望你能卖掉你的，害死过数十亿人的 人之领 时代大规模杀伤性武器。" 他说道。不知怎的，他的语气让你觉得不真诚。

script:
AddCommodity credits 300000
AdjustRep tritachyon 5
AdjustRepActivePerson 5
AddRemoveAnyItem SPECIAL planetkiller -1
$player.turnedInPlanetkiller = true
AddPotentialContact
$player.ethosMercenary++
$boughtAPlanetkillerFromPlayer
text:
你做出安排，将匿名包裹送到一个自动化仓库 —— 该仓库由 Rayan Arroyo 旗下空壳公司的空壳公司下属的空壳公司运营，只需象征性贿赂即可轻松避免海关扫描。

报酬丰厚。

"以后别再和我提起这件事了。" 他以这句话作为告别。

script:
AddCommodity credits 150000
AdjustRep tritachyon 4
AdjustRepActivePerson 4
AddRemoveAnyItem SPECIAL planetkiller -1
$player.turnedInPlanetkiller = true
AddPotentialContact
$player.ethosMercenary++
$boughtAPlanetkillerFromPlayer
text:
你做出安排，将匿名包裹送到一个自动化仓库 —— 该仓库由 Rayan Arroyo 旗下空壳公司的空壳公司下属的空壳公司运营，只需象征性贿赂即可轻松避免海关扫描。

报酬丰厚。

"以后别再和我提起这件事了。" 他以这句话作为告别。
"祝你好运，" 他说，但你看不出他有多真诚。

conditions:
$isPerson
$id != arroyo
!$player.turnedInPlanetkiller
PlayerHasCargo planetkiller
PK_CMD rightPostToAcceptPK
$personFaction.id == tritachyon

text:
"啊，" $heOrShe摆出一副高贵的微笑。"我很遗憾我们并现在没有任何可供出售的物品，但如果您想提交您的联系方式来浏览其他商品... "

"我们还有一系列令人眼花缭乱的低当量武器，包括 AM 催化聚变装置，在民用和私人军事承包商方面都有着良好的记录。我非常乐意为您提供一个目录，包括我们的 速子科技 全息体验，其中包括我们亲自挑选的一些最受欢迎的物品。"
options:
pk_turnInTT2:"我不是来买的，我是来卖东西的。"
pk_turnInTTCatalog:"我这就带着目录离开。"

text:
"哦！" $heOrShe惊叫道，"请接受我的道歉，$playerSirOrMadam。我们并不经常遇到，呃，这种东西的供应商。"

$HeOrShe快速地在 TriPad 上点击着什么东西，同时欢快的贸易人格瞬间降低了几个档次。

"如果你说的是真的 —— 在付款之前，我们必须让一名技术人员，嗯，检查一下那个东西。请放心，我们会尽最大努力保密。这只不过是 速子科技 尊重我们宝贵合作伙伴的隐私的保障。"
options:
pk_ttFree:"我把行星杀手免费送你怎么样，这样速子科技就会欠我一个人情，一个大大的人情。"
pk_ttPay:协商要求 500,000 星币的报酬
cutCommLink:切断通讯连接

text:
那副高贵的笑容再一次像面具一样凝固在了$heOrShe的脸上。

"我很遗憾地说，这样的安排是不可能的，$playerSirOrMadam。当然了，你必须明白，我们 —— 指我和我的合作伙伴，都欠股东一份投资和利润的量化报告。"

"一个如此重大的开放式承诺是，嗯... "$heOrShe斟词酌句，露出了恶心的表情，最终找到了他$heOrShe想要的形容词。"非商业行为的。"

script:
AddCommodity credits 500000
AdjustRep tritachyon 5
AdjustRepActivePerson 5
AdjustRep hegemony -25
AddRemoveAnyItem SPECIAL planetkiller -1
$player.turnedInPlanetkiller = true
$boughtAPlanetkillerFromPlayer
$player.ethosMercenary++
AddPotentialContact
text:
$PersonName渴望做生意 —— 你推测他们将与相关副总裁就这一发现谈一笔小费。并且，凭借 速子科技 的雄厚财力，支付 500,000 星币并不困难。

一个由精英技术人员组成的小组被派往你的$shipOrFleet，鉴定行星杀手。你的技术官员几乎忍不住要问他们关于那些先进鉴定仪器的问题，但工作很快就完成了，交易也得到了确认。

你发了一笔小财，行星杀手喂进了 速子科技 这部巨大的企业机器之中，自此销声匿迹。

script:
AddTextSmall "获得了速子科技武器目录的全息图" highlight
FireAll PopulateOptions
text: "发给您了，" $heOrShe高兴地说着，一边在 TriPad 上点来点去。"希望您能尽快选择与我们做生意。"

id: # Handing in the PK - Sindrian Diktat

conditions:
$isPerson
$id != macario
$id != hyder
$id != caden
!$demandedExecutor
!$global.preparingExecutor
!$player.turnedInPlanetkiller
PlayerHasCargo planetkiller
PK_CMD rightPostToAcceptPK
$personFaction.id == sindrian_diktat
options: pk_giveToDiktat:"我有一些辛达瑞亚之狮很感兴趣的东西。"
notes: # I mean, giving the PK to one of the big 3 might be neat, but definitely requires re-writing the interaction in a unique voice, per. I'll leave a TODO for myself... -dgb

text: $HeOrShe几乎没有抬眼看你，"那是什么？"
options:
pk_giveToDiktat1:"一台完好无损的行星杀手。"
pk_giveToDiktat1nm:"哦，其实什么都没有。我口误了。"

text:
这个辛达强权$Rank的表情稍微精彩了那么一下。

"死太空佬。" $heOrShe低声抱怨了一句，几乎没让你听见。

这好像引起了$hisOrHer的注意。"我明白了。" $heOrShe眯起眼睛说，"你应该把你说的行星杀手交给我保管以... 证实你的说法。当然了，未经最高元首的直接授权，持有这种武器是非法的。"

"这件事很微妙，你肯定知道。" $heOrShe低声说道，"想象一下 Opis 事件重演 —— 反叛的恐怖分子炸毁了自己的卫星，以此来挑战 Andrada 上将的权威！"

$heOrShe安抚道，"当然，我保证你能得到补偿。10,000 星币。
options:
pk_diktatComply:交出行星杀手
pk_diktatComplyHappy:"乐意之至，让我们一起，为了最高元首的荣耀！"
pk_diktatCredits:"对你那荣耀的狮王来说，一台行星杀手至少值 500,000 星币。"
pk_diktatExecutor:"一台行星杀手至少值一艘全新的 执行官-级 战列舰，你不这样认为吗？"
cutCommLink:切断通讯连接

script:
AddCommodity credits 10000
AdjustRep sindrian_diktat 5
AdjustRepActivePerson 5
AddRemoveAnyItem SPECIAL planetkiller -1
$player.turnedInPlanetkiller = true
AddPotentialContact
$global.gavePKtoDiktat = true
text:
你遵照 $rank 的要求，允许一支技术小队登上你的$shipOrFleet来检查并带走行星杀手。

辛达强权 $rank 眉开眼笑。"狮王对那些为他的伟大事业服务的人很慷慨，并且我 —— 你，肯定会因为你为他的最终胜利做出的小小贡献而得到认可。"

最后，带着满意的笑容，$heOrShe正要关闭通讯链接，停顿了一下，然后拍了拍$hisOrHer额头。"我差点忘了你的报酬。" $heOrShe在数据平板上轻轻一点。"看到了吗？咱们两个都会因服务于最高元首而得到奖励。"

script:
AddCommodity credits 20000
AdjustRep sindrian_diktat 10
AdjustRepActivePerson 10
AddRemoveAnyItem SPECIAL planetkiller -1
$player.turnedInPlanetkiller = true
AddPotentialContact
$global.gavePKtoDiktat = true
$player.ethosOrder++
text:
你热情地履行了 $rank 的要求，欢迎一支技术小队登上你的$shipOrFleet来检查并带走行星杀手。

辛达强权 $rank 紧随其后，表达了自己对最高元首的热烈钦佩。"狮王对那些为他的伟大事业和永恒愿景服务的人很慷慨！你和我肯定会得到认可和奖励，。" 这时，$heOrShe向你眨了眨眼，"为我们对他的最终胜利做出的贡献。啊，我们干脆把赏金加倍吧，辛达强权为那些服务于它的人服务，你认可吗？" 

$HeOrShe露出满意的笑容，把这个问题留作一句反问，一边目送行星杀手被送进某个秘密武器库。

"岂有此理！" $heOrShe吼道，"光凭你竟敢提出这种要求这一点，我就应当以颠覆罪将你立马传唤！你... 你这是亲自背叛了最高元首描绘下的伟大愿景！"

辛达强权的 $Rank 深吸了一口气，然后竭尽全力威胁道，"交出行星杀手，马上！"
options:
pk_diktatComply:交出行星杀手
pk_diktatCredits2:"有趣，我可不记得我对 Andrada 宣誓效忠过。我的要价还是 500,000 星币。"
cutCommLink:切断通讯链接

script:
AddCommodity credits 500000
AdjustRep sindrian_diktat -10
AdjustRepActivePerson -25
AddRemoveAnyItem SPECIAL planetkiller -1
$player.turnedInPlanetkiller = true
$global.gavePKtoDiktat = true
$global.soldPKtoDiktat = true
$player.ethosMercenary++
text: "你的自私和贪婪将不会被忘记，$playerName。"

"岂有此理！" $heOrShe吼道，"光凭你竟敢提出这种要求这一点，我就应当以颠覆罪将你立马传唤！你... 你这是亲自背叛了最高元首描绘下的伟大愿景！"

辛达强权的 $Rank 深吸了一口气，然后竭尽全力威胁道，"交出行星杀手，马上！"
options:
pk_executorInsist:"我的要价不变。如果你花点时间动动脑子，我想你会发现这很合理。"
pk_executorSpecial:"我的要价不变。哦，还请确保把你家狮心守卫那些 '特殊' 改造拆干净。"
cutCommLink:切断通讯连接

text:
辛达强权 $Rank 的脸红得相当别扭，就连$heOrShe喘出来的气都粗重了不少，但你的提议在其看来似乎仍旧有些道理。

"我必须请示我的上级。" $heOrShe咬牙切齿地说，然后猛地挂掉了通讯链接。

你盯着旋转的 辛达强权 徽标看了一会，徽标后面一直播放着鼓吹 辛达瑞亚之狮 最伟大胜利的全息宣传影像，宣传内容却难说有多少说服力。

script:
Highlight "一个星期"
AdjustRep sindrian_diktat -10
AdjustRepActivePerson -25
$demandedExecutor = true
$global.preparingExecutor = true 7
$removeSpecialModifications = false
MakeNearbyFleetsNonHostile sindrian_diktat pk 20000 8
text:
面前的图像中，Volturn 上身着动力装甲的士兵正在 '获得解放' 的人民的欢呼致意中列队前行。而很快那个辛达强权 $Rank 就带着一副刚被训斥过的神色接入了通讯。

"我的上级批准了你那些...请求。" $heOrShe说道，脸色就像吃了条虫子般难看，"我们需要一个星期的时间来安排，到时候再回来敲定这笔交易。"

"另外，尽管这并非我本意，但附近的巡逻队已经都都接到了...容忍你存在的...建议。"

说完这句话，$heOrShe狠狠挂掉了通讯链接。

script:
Highlight "一个星期"
AdjustRep sindrian_diktat -25
AdjustRepActivePerson -50
$demandedExecutor = true
$global.preparingExecutor = true 7
$removeSpecialModifications = true
MakeNearbyFleetsNonHostile sindrian_diktat pk 20000 8
text:
面前的图像中，Volturn 上被 '解放' 的人民们正在向着列队行军的士兵欢呼致意。而很快那个辛达强权 $Rank 就带着一副刚被训斥过的神色接入了通讯。

"我的上级批准了你那些...有辱人格的勒索。" $heOrShe说道，脸色就像吃了条虫子般难看，"我们需要一个星期的时间来安排，到时候再回来敲定这笔交易。"

"另外，就我个人而言，我更愿意把你当作恐怖分子来逮捕并处决。但附近的巡逻队都收到了...容忍你存在的...建议。"

说完这句话，$heOrShe狠狠挂掉了通讯链接。

"喂，你。" $heOrShe用发自真心的厌恶和讥讽语气传递了$heOrShe对你的所有看法。

"我们还没准备好。"

辛达强权的 $Rank 猛然挂掉了通讯链接。

script:
AddRemoveAnyItem SPECIAL planetkiller -1
AdjustRep hegemony -50
$player.turnedInPlanetkiller = true
PK_CMD giveExecutor $removeSpecialModifications
$global.gavePKtoDiktat = true
$global.soldPKtoDiktatForExecutor = true
unset $global.preparingExecutor
text:
"一切就绪了。" $heOrShe语气讥讽，"执行官-级 战列舰，此等尤物的精美绝伦就凭你可永远都品味不出来。"

$HeOrShe旋即切断了通讯链接，留下一名虽然困惑但忠诚无疑的下级军官来做出实际安排。一支技术小队接管了行星杀手，并把它从你的$shipOrFleet移送给辛达强权保管。

只有 Andrada 才知道它以后派得上怎样的用场。

id: # Handing in the PK - Luddic Church

conditions:
$isPerson
$id != arroyo
!$player.turnedInPlanetkiller
PlayerHasCargo planetkiller
PK_CMD rightPostToAcceptPK
$personFaction.id == luddic_church
options: pk_turnInChurch:"我想聊聊行星杀手的事。"

conditions:
$isPerson
$id != arroyo
!$player.turnedInPlanetkiller
PlayerHasCargo planetkiller
PK_CMD rightPostToAcceptPK
$personFaction.id == luddic_church
$temporarilyIgnoreYou
text: "从这里滚出去！" $HeOrShe吼道，随后关闭了通讯。
"这没什么好说的。" $PersonName皱眉说到， "它们存在是对一切至圣至善之物的亵渎。它们的存在便是对全人类和神的原罪。"
options:
pk_turnInChurch2:"我希望把一个行星杀手置于教会的监管下。"
pk_turnInChurchAvoid:"啊，好吧，我会尽量避开它们的。"
cutCommLink:切断通讯链接

text:
"什么？！" $HeOrShe惊讶地倒退。"我祈祷你只是个编造蹩脚笑话的骗子。假如你真的持有此魔物，我恳求你立刻将其远远带离此地，或者将其毁灭！否，否则骑士团会来处置你的！"

"不要再和我说话。" $heOrShe红着脸说道，随后重重地关闭了通讯链接。
"嗯，不错。"$HeOrShe满腹狐疑地打量着你。"你还有什么想讨论的吗？"

id: # Handing in the PK to the Luddic Knights at Ceyx

conditions:
$id == ceyx score:100
!$player.turnedInPlanetkiller score:1000
PlayerHasCargo planetkiller
$player.commissionFactionId == luddic_church
text: 你的$shipOrFleet 接近 $entityName.
options:
pkCeyx:用卢德骑士团的标准频率开启通讯链接。
defaultLeave:离开

text:
作为 银河救赎教会 正式雇佣的战斗员，你接收到了一系列密码能够让你更加方便的和其他战斗员以及 卢德骑士团 协调行动。

你使用此信息进入了骑士团在 Ceyx 的通讯系统。

一位 卢德骑士团 的成员出现在你面前，根据你的通讯数据，他是一位 行星教卫。

"我是 Gideon Oak，" 他说道，严厉的视线紧盯着你。

之后他如顽石一般开始耐心地等待。
options:
pk_giveKnights:"我手上有个 行星杀手 级武器，我来此将其交予 卢德骑士团 保管。"
cutCommLink:切断通讯链接

text:
行星教卫 Gideon Oak 又一次出现在你面前。

"$playerName 舰长。" 他问候到，严厉的视线紧盯着你。

之后他如顽石一般开始耐心地等待。
options:
pk_giveKnights:"我手上有个 行星杀手 级武器，我来此将其交予 卢德骑士团 保管。"
cutCommLink:切断通讯链接

text:
"嗯..."他沉吟半晌，似是在逐字逐句的考量你刚刚的发言，也在思索你本身可信与否。 

最终，他觉得你还算值得信任，微微点头，说道："我们将依 卢德 圣训，妥帖处置此物。"

"舰长，我们的行为不能让那 霸主 知晓，还请你理解：那 霸主 妄称自己继承了 人之领 遗留的一切古老兵器，若是让他们知道有人摧毁了这样一件兵器，肯定要遭他们怨恨的。"
options:
pkGiveKnightsConfirm:"我理解，现在我就会将 行星杀手 交予你方。"
cutCommLink:切断通讯链接

script:
AddStoryPoints 3
AdjustRep luddic_church 15
AdjustRepActivePerson 5
AddRemoveAnyItem SPECIAL planetkiller -1
$player.turnedInPlanetkiller = true
$player.turnedInPlanetkillerToKnights = true
$player.ethosOrder++
text:
一位审判官-舰长领着一队骑士登上了你的$shipOrFleet。他们仔细检查了行星杀手装置，念了几句驱邪祷语，然后把它搬走了。

"你信守了 对 卢德 的信徒之承诺，$playerName。" 行星教卫说道，"愿 卢德 赞美您的善举。"

他的脸上没有笑容，但透漏出了极其微小的一丝暖意。

script:
FireBest PKSentinelDockyardInteract
$tradeMode = OPEN 0
$menuState = main 0
FireAll PopulateOptions
text: 尽管这片由多台临时的龙门吊架组成的一次性集合体只能勉强算得上 "船坞" ，但其上仍然留存着被用来临场修复整支大型舰队的痕迹。

script:
$global.pk_exploredSentinelGantry = true
AddTextSmall "发现了 哨戒船坞 " highlight
text:
"我敢打赌这是霸主留下的东西，有不少年头了。" 你的行动长官嘟哝着，"估计能追溯到第一次AI战争时期。"

你的传感器技师问起了这个结论的依据，但行动人员们只是摇了摇头，低语着什么这是他们的 "直觉" 一类的话。

传感器操作员们在运行了又一次扫描后，向你示意到，"$PlayerSirOrMadam，这座船坞里还有几艘被遗弃于此的舰艇，看起来像是第十四军团的老古董了。"

"霸主留下的玩意，有些年头了。" 你的行动长官咕哝着说到，"我敢打赌是第一次 AI 战争时期的的东西。"

这里肯定就是 哨戒星 上的原舰队船员回收再利用他们舰队里一切还能发挥作用的东西 —— 与改装舰船的地方了。

你的传感器技师运行了一次扫描，示意你过来看看，"$PlayerSirOrMadam，这片残骸带里还有些被遗弃的舰船，看起来像是第十四军团的老古董了。"

script:
$global.pkCacheDefendersDefeated = true
AddTextSmall "发现了第十四战斗群舰队使用过 AI 战舰 的痕迹" highlight
text:
你从技术专家那里收到了一份令人不安的战后简报：你的舰队刚刚与之交手的 第十四军团 战舰的指令控制中心似乎进行过为了能够适配AI核心操控的全系统改造。

这看起来更像是霸主自己的改造，而不是速子科技的杰作。

id: # PK Sentinel-related (the world the crews offloaded to)

script:
AddRemoveAnyItem SPECIAL planetkiller 1
$global.pk_recovered = true
RemoveOption pk_sentinelDevOptSetFoundPK

$player.encounteredPKDefenderFleet = true
AddTextSmall "遭遇了自律型第十四战斗群舰队" highlight
RemoveOption pk_sentinelDevOptSetSawFleet

$global.pkCacheDefendersDefeated = true
AddTextSmall "发现了第十四战斗群舰队使用过 AI 战舰的痕迹" highlight
RemoveOption pk_sentinelDevOptSetKilledFleet

$global.pk_exploredSentinelGantry = true
AddTextSmall "发现了 哨戒船坞" highlight
RemoveOption pk_sentinelDevOptSetGantry

conditions:
$core_pkPlanet score:1000
!$hasMarket
!$global.leftCrewOnSentinel
!$global.discoveredSentinel
Highlight  "transmits a weak transponder signal"
text:
$fullName 凛冽刺骨的地表在你的下方缓缓转动着，这颗星球的两极仅有无尽的寒冬。在这种气候状况下，只有极少数较为幸运的地区适宜人类居住。

而这里的确有人居住：在星球表面其中一个宜居的角落，侦测到了一丝微弱的无线电信号。这缕若有若无的微弱信号传递着一条使用霸主标准协议的应答器编码，种类有些老旧，但依旧能够识别。

传感器扫描辨识出了这里存在着一个有些许农业和原始工业迹象的小型聚落。

options: pkSentinel_tryComms:在通讯频道里对信号作出应答

pkSentinel_shuttle:搭乘穿梭机下往地表调查
defaultLeave:离开

script:
SetOptionColor pk_sentinelDevOptSetFoundPK gray
SetOptionColor pk_sentinelDevOptSetSawFleet gray
SetOptionColor pk_sentinelDevOptSetKilledFleet gray
SetOptionColor pk_sentinelDevOptSetGantry gray
SetOptionColor dev_PKnexusHackTest gray
options:
pk_sentinelDevOptSetFoundPK:DEV set found PK
pk_sentinelDevOptSetSawFleet:DEV set encountered XIV fleet
pk_sentinelDevOptSetKilledFleet:DEV set defeated XIV fleet
pk_sentinelDevOptSetGantry:DEV set found Gantries
dev_PKnexusHackTest:DEV test nexus hack dialog

text:
你发送的标准通讯请求并未得到任何答复。这颗星球的地表上没有通讯器网络，甚至连一台紧急求生通讯器都没有，就算有也应该全坏了，或是无法建立通讯链接。

你的通讯官尝试采用一系列非常规手段，从一套用来定位从 人之领 时代以来就在深空中飘流的遗物的旧式通讯标准，再到一套容易用传感器阵列背景噪声掩盖的地下帮派专用最新低保真通讯标准，能让正派的海关人员板起脸侧目而视的那种。但这些尝试最终都只是徒劳罢了。

"$PlayerSirOrMadam，我们说不定只能用老办法和他们接触了。" 你的通讯官带着一丝歉意向你报告。

你踏下了穿梭机，结满霜冻的地面在你的靴底吱嘎作响。尽管周围寒风刺骨，但环境防护服保证了你舒适无虞。

那片聚落距此约有一公里远。出于基本的礼节，你的着陆地点选在了一处多石的高地上，尽量避免震动打扰到那片看起来像是在尝试进行某些农作活动的灰色泥地。

script: AddTextSmall "找到了失落的哨戒殖民地" highlight
text:
一群身着面罩与兜帽的当地住民在途中与你们会面了。

这群人的护卫们在队伍的后方，将随身的标准预制型人之领卡宾枪收了起来，吊在背带上。他们的衣着不过是些改制再利用后的勤务合成服，就是在负责管理货舱和钻维护通道的人员身上会看到的那种。但他们的身上依旧有着一些像是装饰品的，用来表明职务与地位，磨损严重但依旧擦得锃亮的军徽 —— 还有双翼绽开的凤凰与群星。这群人就是 霸主 的幸存船员了，而且根据他们的样子来看，这群人已经在这里待了相当，相当长的一段时间了。

他们的领队走上前来，摘下了她的护目镜。"我们赢了吗？" 她问到。
options: pk_sentinel1:"第一次 AI 战争还是第二次？"

text:
头领与她的同伴们交换着眼神，尝试着接受你话里的言外之意。

你受邀进入了他们的聚落，寻一个稍微暖和一点的场所继续谈话。至少这些落难者依旧没有忘记基本的待客之道 —— 至少是以他们的标准来说。

亦或者，是他们的头领 —— 一位被她的 "中尉" 们称呼为 "指挥官" 的，名叫 Alo Skiron 的长老 —— 明智地选择了一种能够将从星区中传来的，易于让人反应过激的新消息传播控制在最低限度的手段。

你被带往了一群简单，低矮的建筑群中。这些建筑大多由土方，星舰的船体结构板构成，而烟囱和预铸玻璃则点缀其中。街道十分干净，而居民们都根据自己职业的不同身着对应的制服。尽管他们的目光都毫无保留地盯着你们一行人，但没有一人停下自己手上的工作。

Skiron 指挥官将你和你的团队迎进了一座中心议会厅。这里不仅相当温暖，还装饰着 霸主 相关的随身装备：制服，武器，补给箱盖上抠下的徽记等等。这些手工制作的纪念物几乎让你以为这是一座卢德圣地，只不过进行了一些翻修，好重新用来敬拜一位军武之神。

你假装抿了一口 Skrion 的侍从端上来的劣质酵母衍生物代茶 —— 说不定是代咖啡？
options:
pk_sentinel3:继续听
pk_sentinel3b:"嗯，这茶味道不坏。"

text:
"你们是从 核心世界 来的，对吗？" Skiron 开口问到，"我们必须和正式的指挥链重新建立联系，一切皆为纪律之命。"

在她身后，侍从与守卫们一起咕哝着相似的话语。你觉得你好像听到了 "纪律" 二字。

"你愿意将我们的消息传达给第 十四战斗群 之 英仙座霸主 吗？他们肯定幸存下来了，对吗？纪律保证了你会得到嘉奖，而我们则会得到 —— 救赎。"

(在她身后，你又听到了人们齐声，用好似又不似祈祷与合唱的声音反复念着 "嘉奖与救赎"，)

现在 Skiron 像是看见了她信仰中的救世主一般，眼底正散发着奇异的微光。而与此同时，那眼神中在狂热之下也还埋藏着些许恐惧，甚至是惊慌，因为你是个外来者。

他们这里从来就没有过外来者。

notes: # make sure the player has at least one thing to confront Skiron with, otherwise remove the option

options: pk_sentinelShowHegCom:向他们展示你的 霸主 雇佣合约
pk_sentinelGiveDatapads:帮她了解星区最近的情况和历史
pk_sentinelHubConfront:与 Skiron 就你所掌握的现状对质
pk_sentinelHubMedicalCases:安排将患者送往 霸主 治下的宙域进行治疗
pk_sentinelLeaveCrew:"我可以留下 100 名船员，他们可以作为专家与技师协助你的殖民地。"

script:
SetEnabled pk_sentinelLeaveCrew false
SetTooltip pk_sentinelLeaveCrew "只有当你的$shipOrFleet内有 200 名以上的船员时你才能这样做。"

notes: # can't ask questions if you already asked them all!

text: Skiron 看起来无动于衷。"纪律严禁我们为了达成非战略目的而与他人分享情报，" 她说到，"但让你提几个问题也无妨。"
"但纪律允许在有条件的情况下与他人共享情报，" Skiron 有些犹豫地看了你一眼，说到，"我们感谢你在这方面的直截了当，所以问吧。"
"根据纪律，我们应当与盟友共享情报，" Skiron 如对待一个同志般向你点头致意，"我们有问必答。"

options: pk_sentinelAskDangerVague:"我觉得这里有些你没有告诉我的危险存在。"
pk_sentinelAskDangerSpecific:"你能告诉我那些仍处于活跃状态的 速子科技 AI 舰队是怎么回事吗？"
pk_sentinelAskProtocols:"你能不能跟我说说和这些 '纪律' 有关的事？"
pk_sentinelAskWhereFrom:"跟我说说，你们这群人是如何在这里生活的？"

text: 你思忖着自己已有的发现 。出于 Skiron 对 '纪律' 的遵从，她或许并不会对你袒露一切，但或许只要你将某些难以辩驳的证据摆在她面前，就能够从她口中钓出更多的细节。
你思忖着自己已有的发现 。尽管你们已经在有限的程度上分享了情报，但你依旧怀疑自己能够从死守 '纪律' 的 Skiron 身上获取多少具有直接价值的情报。
你思忖着自己已有的发现 。看起来 Skiron 对你的 霸主 雇佣协议深信不疑，因此只要你将自己现有的情报与她交换，她似乎会很乐意为你补上这些事件之间的空白。

options: pk_sentinelAskGantry:"我找到你们轨道上的船坞了，但没看到你们的舰队。"
pk_sentinelFoundYourFleet:"我和你们的舰队打过照面了，它们当时正处于 AI 控制下的自律状态。"
pk_sentinelFoundFleetAI:"听着，我知道你的舰队经过了可以让他们被 AI 核心操控的改造，我这有证据。"
pk_sentinelFoundPK:"我找到你们的舰队留下的行星杀手了。"

notes: # make sure the player has at least one thing to confront Skiron with, otherwise remove the option

# confronts done, force return to base convo
# maybe acknowledge this? Maybe not.

text:
你从自己的 TriPad 上调出了自己的 霸主 证明文件，将它们展示给 Skiron 以供确认。

她小心地看了你一眼，便将眼神转向了屏幕。她键入了某些代码，喃喃自语着一些口令，而你的证明文件也对此作出了正确的回应。Skiron 停住了片刻，决定将 TriPad 递还给你，小心翼翼地就好像这是某种无可替代的文物。

script:
$gainedSomeTrust = true
$showedHegCommission = true
AdjustRepPerson skiron FRIENDLY 10
FireAll PKSentinelHubOptions
text:
"就算这是 速子科技 或者某种 AI 攻破了我们的资安也不奇怪，但据你所言，我还是愿意相信你，自称隶属于 霸主 海军辅助军的 $PlayerName 舰长。"

她的脸上并没有流露出任何的笑意，但紧张的气氛还是消散无踪了。守卫们从她的话语中感到了些许安心，而她的中尉们相视而笑。

(你听到其中的某人说到 "赞美指挥部"。)

你的一个随行警卫递了一个小书包给你，里面装了些预载有星区近况读本的数据平板。

这是打捞者游走于边缘世界时的常备之物，只要付一小笔订阅费用就能持续更新。统计数据显示，这些读物能有效地帮助那些与世隔绝许久的难民重新融入社会，无论对方是低温冷冻者，船难幸存者，还是文明丧失地的居民。

Skiron 一行人像对待圣物般接过了你的数据平板，小心翼翼地触碰着它。即使动作有些迟疑，但他们还是知道如何使用那些交互界面。不过很显然，他们已经在很长，很长一段时间里，与稍微复杂些的纳米锻炉制品无缘了。

script:
$gaveDatapads = true
$gainedSomeTrust = true
AdjustRepPerson skiron FRIENDLY 2
FireAll PKSentinelHubOptions
text:
你和几个高级军官听着这群人小声讨论着当前的局势与时事；他们口中的方言的确与当下的英仙座星区有些脱轨，但并不比你见过的一些冬眠者身上的案例更严重。

"我们感谢你提供的情报，舰长。" Skiron 说到，同时将数据平板交还给你。"许多事情都变了，但知道了指挥部仍然存在，并依旧等待着我们回去报到，使我们倍感欣慰。"

("指挥部即为救赎，" 在她身后，人们齐声说到。)

Skiron 指挥官在开口前思量了片刻。

"我们是活跃于 AI 战争时期的霸主舰队乘员的后代。因为自我们降落于此已经过去了百年之久，原先的舰员没有一个能存活至今，但我们依旧维持着指挥链的存续。" 她摩挲着她那身 '制服' 上的霸主徽标，"就如霸主的标准失联应对协议一般，协议即为我们生存的关键。"

("协议即为生机，" 他们在 Skiron 身后齐声念到。)

你谨慎地将话题从所谓的 "纪律" 上岔开，询问起了这些落难船员是如何生存下来的。

Skiron 与你谈起他们是如何建起居所遮风挡雨，还有他们曾经面临的困境 —— 漫长的冬天，短缺的食物，还有在舰员之中如何维持纪律。不过她还是因为某些 "战术上的考量" 而对诸多细节有所保留，但就像无数你曾经看过的全息剧集的戏码一样，这个借口听起来相当老套。

你感觉 Skiron 肯定在隐瞒着些什么。

在谢过你的开诚布公后，Skiron 指挥官看起来很愿意与你分享她聚落的故事。

"我们是在 AI 战争时期活跃的一支 霸主 舰队幸存乘员的后代。啊，用你的话来说，第一次 AI 战争。" Skiron 解释到，"自从我们降落于此星球后已过去了一百个星历年，原先的乘员里没有一个能活到今天，但我们维持着指挥链的延续。" 她抚摸着那身 '制服' 上的霸主徽标，"就如霸主 纪律 中规定的标准失联应对一般，纪律即为生存。"

("纪律即为生机。" 他们在 Skiron 身后齐声念到。)

你谨慎地将话题从所谓的 "纪律" 上岔开，询问起了这些落难船员是如何生存下来的。

Skiron 与你谈起他们是如何建立起能够遮风挡雨的基础设施，如何利用从生存手册中的知识与回收的材料，以及数台从残余的舰船中回收而来的简易纳米锻炉组建起粗糙的基础工业和生体培养设施。这段故事就如许多流行全息剧的戏码一样，展示着这群幸存者惊人的毅力与对环境的适应力。

但，你还是感觉 Skiron 肯定在隐瞒着些什么。

"当然了。" 她点头道，"这些是我们所遵从的规章制度，它们保证了我们能够继续执行任务。我们已经遵从纪律长达 ——" 她用近乎警告般的眼神看向了自己正开始默念某些类似于祈祷的随行人员们，让他们安静了下来，随后，Skiron 将视线移回了你的身上。

"—— 已经长达一百个星历年了。我们遵从着手册上的内容，向后代传授着我们的祖先所接受过的训练。遵从着托付于我们接到的命令，直到新的指令传来，此乃必要之事。"

(在她身后，你听到她的随从们肯定地齐声传出了一句 "当是如此"。)

Skiron 的脸上摆出了一副你早已见过不知道多少次的，除了死板地服从命令外什么都看不出来的冷淡表情。

"纪律禁止我们在战时状态下向无关人士透露战略情报，除非得到上级授权。我们必须重新建立与指挥部的联系。"

("指挥部即为救赎，" 人们在她身后齐声说到。)

Skiron 的脸上摆出了一副你早已见过不知道多少次的，除了死板地服从命令外什么都看不出来的冷淡表情。

"纪律禁止我们在战时状态下透露战略情报，除非得到上级授权。"

("指挥部即为救赎，" 人们在她身后齐声说到。)

"但是。" 片刻的停顿后，她面露难色，"我们曾面对过巨大的危机，你应该小心一点，我只能向你透露这么多。"

Skrion 的脸上几乎下意识地摆出了一副抗拒的冷淡表情，但很快就放松了下来。

"纪律严禁我们与没有得到指挥部授权的人士透露重要的战略信息，" 她说到，"但作为霸主签约下的辅助军官，你理应得到一份简报。"

她深吸了一口气，便继续说了下去。"我们接到的命令是摧毁其中一个 速子科技 AI 战斗舰队的集合点，一座颇具规模的自律太空站。我们最后得到的情报是其仍旧处于建造的过程当中，但是..."
options: pk_sentinelAskAboutStarships2:"那支舰队武装齐全，依旧处于运作状态。"

text:
"没错，而且还跟着一整支 AI 舰队大军。我们的祖先最终得以脱离战斗，但他们的大部分后勤舰船都损失殆尽了。"

"他们的舰队无法返回核心世界，所以只能凑出余下的燃料让一支小型先遣队带着他们失败的战报回程。但很显然，那支先遣队肯定是被中途拦截了。"

"我们的祖先从古老的调查数据中找到了哨戒星，离他们最近的宜居世界。于是便在回收利用一切可以利用的东西后，在这里安家落户了下来。"
options: pk_sentinelAskAboutStarships3:"从一整支舰队打捞回收的材料可建的起的聚落要比你们现在这座可大的多啊。"

text:
"你的确观察到了不少东西，" Skrion 承认到。

"直到指挥部的命令传来前，我不会再向你透露半个字，希望你能见谅，$playerSirOrMadam。"

Skrion 和她手下的中尉们快速交换了一个眼神，"在收到来自指挥部的新命令前，我们必须坚守职责。"

("职责即为生命，" 他们在她身后默念到。)

"在接收到新命令之前，我们的职责就是坚守岗位。" Skiron 和她的中尉们交换了一个眼神，"不过..."

她与顾问们商讨片刻之后，转过头来对你说到，"有些医疗条件只有核心世界才能够提供，而我们正好需要，呃，转送几名病情严重的患者接受治疗。我确定指挥部肯定会负责照顾他们的健康状况的。"

"而且，" 在片刻尴尬的停顿过后，她继续说到，"我也很确定，你肯定会得到相应的报酬的。"

你随即命令自己的事务长安排将哨戒星殖民地上的病患接收到舰上。

经过初步诊疗后，舰上的大家发现，因为缺少许多医疗科技，也因为此地严酷的生存环境，那些病患的情况简直算得上骇人听闻。他们的状况与某些有关旧地球历史 —— 或者是几个贫穷的核心世界里的社会底层生存状况的严肃全息纪录片里的描述别无二致。

"这是储藏我们收集的材料的中转站，都是用来建造村落的。" Skiron 带着一张奉令办事的单调脸色说道。

你很明白这个表情，这是下级不想撒谎，却想要对上级隐瞒一些事情时的样子。这种时候，对方只会精确回答你所问的问题，不多说一句。

"是的，我们的祖先建造了一个临时船坞用以储藏和分配我们所收集的材料，用以建造村落。" Skiron 说道，她脸色及口气都体现出一种只是在奉命办事的感觉。

你很明白这个表情，这是下级不想撒谎，却想要对上级隐瞒一些事情时的样子。这种时候，对方只会精确回答你所问的问题，不多说一句。
"是的，我们的祖先建造了一个临时船坞用以储藏和分配我们所收集的材料，用以建造村落。" Skiron 停顿了一下，继续说道。"也用以重新改造舰队的剩余战力。"
对于剩余的舰队，她没说一个字。
对于将舰队改造成了一个忠心于 霸主 的无人舰队这事，她只字未提。
这样一支像 速子科技 一样使用AI核心操控舰船却隶属于 霸主 的舰队简直闻所未闻。
"对此我无话可说。$playerSirOrMadam。" 她脸色僵硬地否定道。
Skiron 双眼圆睁，但是她成功地控制了自己的语调。 "我不能提及那事，$playerSirOrMadam。" 她说到，脸色僵硬。

Skiron 双眼圆睁，但是她成功地控制了自己的语调。 "啊。" 她说到， "我真的不能再说更多... 关于那事。得遵守纪律。"

"但是，"她近乎哀求地看着你，似乎想从她的思维中抽离那至高无上的纪律 。"作为一位忠于 霸主 的公民，不论正式受雇与否，如果成功地夺回了任何大规模杀伤性武器，那该公民应当将武器尽快并低调的归还给 霸主 官方保管。"

她长叹一声，弱弱地补充道。"当然，我只是打个比方。"

她身后的副官们僵硬地假装没有听到他们刚刚得到的信息。
"我不会认定或否定任何你所谓的结论或推断。$playerSirOrMadam。" Skiron说道， "我建议我们换个话题。"

"我不能认定或否定任何你指出的所谓事实或者推论，$playerSirOrMadam。" Skiron 说道，"如你所见，我们这里并没有进行太空航行的能力，而且除非指挥部解除加密，否则我亦无权讨论过去的行动。"

她双手交叉。"我建议我们换个话题。"

"舰长。" Skiron 倾过身子，像个老战友般低声说到 "您是个领导者，以及 霸主 海军的 辅助军。您明白指挥的重要。主动性的重要。我不了解 核心世界，但我懂如何在边远星区生存。"

她深吸了一口气，然后缓缓吐出。"不论前人到底干了什么，我相信他们尽职地完成了他们的任务。如果他们，或者我们需要向任何人负责，那我的使命便是向指挥部负责。"

她提高声音，向所有的在场的人发话。"因此我会这么做。最为指挥官，我对我们任务的执行负全责。我会一直如此，直到指挥部另有安排，或我尽忠而亡。"

("指挥部便是救赎！"人们在她身后喊道，再一次表明了他们的忠心。对 Skiron 的忠心，又或是对他们任务的忠心。)

Skiron 一动不动地观察了你很久。她的卫兵都紧张不安地来回移动，不过都还是把武器挂在肩上。她的副官们小心维持着中立地表情。

她闭眼深吸了口气，似乎下定了决心。

Skiron 站了起来，她的副官们急匆匆地跟随其后，阶梯状站在她身后。

"我们对话的时间结束了，舰长。我感谢你的参观。"

她的卫兵向前。

Skiron 站了起来，她的副官们急匆匆地跟随其后，阶梯状站在她身后。

她的卫兵向前。

"清空这房间。" 她说到，"舰长 和我会单独留下。"

所有人无声的排成一排离开。几个 Skiron 的人给了你个奇怪的眼光。

在厚重的门轻轻关上之后，Skiron 叹了口气，坐了下去。她随后托着下巴看向你。

"我不确定你想得到什么。和其他人相比，你最该知道维持纪律的重要性。"

options: pk_sentinelConfrontAIRespA2:"那支舰队袭击了我们。你们的祖先可算是留下了好一个致命陷阱。"
pk_sentinelConfrontAIRespB2:"真相必须被揭露，无论是多令人不快的真相。"
pk_sentinelConfrontAIRespC2:"为了大多数人的利益，我愿意对此缄口不提。"
pk_sentinelConfrontAIRespD2:"只要有个合适的价钱，我也是愿意乖乖闭嘴的。"
pk_sentinelConfrontAIRespE2:"根据 霸主 的法律，在战争中使用 AI 的行径属于犯罪。"
pk_sentinelConfrontAIRespF2:"强迫 AI 们为你们的战争卖命是不人道的。"
pk_sentinelConfrontAIRespH2:" AI 们是趁手的工具，你们当初做了正确的事。"

text:
"战争会洒下致命的种子。" Skiron 说道，她低头看向破烂的舱壁上的 霸主 徽标，"战争把无辜者征召起来，送他们去死，将人心铸造成无情的机器。"

"不论过去做了什么，你还活着，我们也是。"

"空谈起来这是个值得赞许的原则，舰长。" 她说到。 "但我好奇你是否对你自己的船员也能向对你自己一般爽快地给与真相。"

"不过没必要再空谈这些猜测了。" Skiron 给你一个严厉的眼神。 "只要你能遵守我们维护纪律的需要，我也能尊重你的原则。这不是个温和的世界。我们的生存要优先于你高贵的信念，不然下场便是死亡。"

她转身面对舱壁上从某一 第十四战斗群 舰艇上搜来的 霸主 徽标。 "把你的真相带回 核心世界 ，让指挥部做我们的审判员吧。"

"我认为我们之间的交谈已经结束了。"

"我很高兴听你这么说。" Skiron 说道 "不过你确实选了个奇怪的机会来宣扬你对此的信念，舰长。"

"不论如何，会审判我们 —— 还有我们祖先 —— 的是指挥部，由他们来决定我们的功过。"

她看向镶入伤痕累累的舱壁上的巨大 第十四战斗群 徽标。"我相信我们已经理解了彼此的立场。谢谢你来此。"

"我必须承认，舰长，我以为你所奋斗的事业会更加崇高。 或许过去百星历年来 辅助军 的标准已经不如以往了。"

"不论如何。武器是工具，驾驭武器者也一样。英仙座 霸主 会放弃有用的工具吗？不会。" 她给你个意味深长地眼神，似乎是承认了她所指的并非仅仅是雇佣兵。

"如果你想要 星币，我们这里没有。" 她继续道，"你汇报我们的坐标后，指挥部会处理你们的账单。既然我们已了解彼此的立场，我认为我们的对话就此结束了。"

她看向你。"我想 英仙座霸主 的军事目标要高于针对平民的法律。对表里不一的顾虑只存在于温和的世界之上。"

"至于你的观点，会审判我们 —— 还有我们祖先 —— 的是指挥部，由他们来决定我们的功过。"

她看向镶入伤痕累累的舱壁上的巨大 第十四战斗群 徽标。"我相信我们已经理解了彼此的立场。谢谢你来此。"

"我还没听说过靠良心打赢的战争，舰长。你要明白，在边缘星系，我们可没时间悲天悯人。"

"不论如何，" Skiron 挥手，似乎试图打散这个话题。 "事情已成。武器是工具，驾驭武器者也一样。英仙座霸主 既接受志愿兵，又招募动员兵。若一支军队想要取得胜利，那它又为什么会放弃有用的工具呢？" 她抛下了这一尖锐的问题，没有回答。

"会审判我们 —— 还有我们祖先 —— 的是指挥部，由他们来决定我们的功过。"

她看向镶入伤痕累累的舱壁上的巨大 第十四战斗群 徽标。"我相信我们已经理解了彼此的立场。谢谢你来此。"

"我们之中还有 卢德 教徒认同你的观点。" 她说道， "但他们也清楚地明白忍让乃是事之常理。难道核心世界已经忘了这一点吗？"

"不论如何。" Skiron 挥手，似乎试图打散这个话题。 "事情已成。武器是工具，驾驭武器者也一样。既接受志愿兵，又招募动员兵。若有人想要取得胜利，那他又为什么会放弃有用的工具呢？" 她抛下了这一尖锐的问题，没有回答。

"会审判我们 —— 还有我们祖先 —— 的是指挥部，由他们来决定我们的功过。"

她看向镶入伤痕累累的舱壁上的巨大 第十四战斗群 徽标。"我相信我们已经理解了彼此的立场。谢谢你来此。"

"那你便是认同了我祖先的决定。" Skiron 对此似乎并没有特别的欣慰。

"而那个决定也带来了反对。" 她补充道， "甚至是叛乱。" 她的眼神如 Sentinel 荒芜的土地一般冷冽。

"战争会洒下致命的种子。" Skiron 说到，她低头看向破烂的舱壁上的 霸主 徽标。"然后给幸存者留下苦涩的果实。"

"我相信我们已经理解了彼此的立场。谢谢你来此。"

Skiron 又一次面无表情，估计是在心里和纪律的要求做着斗争。考虑一刻后，同情让她的表情柔和了一些。 

"纪律不许我透露机密信息，" Skiron 说道，"但是众所周知，我们的祖先来此和 速子科技 的AI舰队作战。那些AI舰队不像我们... 受制于人类的寿命。"

她双眼略微向上瞥了一下，瞥向那可怖的天穹。

她手下一个 副官 趁这个停顿说道。"一星历年前，天上的光——"

"我们不清楚那是什么！" Skiron 斥停了那个副官，并给他一个要事后处分的眼光。

她整理好了情绪，再度转向你。 "外面可能有某些人，某些东西，依旧存在并且能够运行。我们的观测器不够精密。" 她揉了揉眼角。

"我能说的只有这么多了。"

"是的... 是的，我们大约一星历年前在天上看到了光。" Skiron 说道。

"我们没有先进的设备，所以我们无法区分交战双方。但是从能观测到的引擎光谱 ——还有武器闪光 —— 那不是 速子科技 舰队。"
options: pk_sentinelAskDangerSpecific2:"舰载武器开火的闪光？这片星系里最近发生了战斗吗？"

text:
"唔，" 她看上去有些畏缩。"我们是这样认为的。之前的老船员全都过世了，但他们讲过从遥远的星球上看，这种战斗会是什么样子的，而且... 我们还有训练手册，还有全息视频，虽然大部分现在都坏了。"

"但是我们是按纪律进行了训练的！" 她重整了下姿态，说道。 "确实，我们信息有限，但是我们仔细记录了所有观察到的细节和动作。" ("纪律即真理。"人们在她身后说道。) 

"据我们分析，那是一场有主宰纪元到核心纪元舰船参加的战斗，偶尔还能观测到高能光谱闪烁。" 提供这些报告时，她看上去紧张但自豪。

"不论参战的是谁...是什么，至少它们都没有联系我们。"

script:
AddCommodity crew -100
AdjustRepPerson skiron FRIENDLY 5
$global.leftCrewOnSentinel = true
PK_CMD convertSentinelToColony
FireAll PKSentinelHubOptions
text:
Skiron 笑道 "那就谢谢你了，$playerName舰长。有了他们的帮助，我们可以解决很多问题，把这里打造为一个指挥部也能认可的哨站。直到收到指挥部的联络，纪律将引导我们。"

("纪律将引导我们。" 她身后的众人重复道。)

你令你的副官按照安排开工。一些训练有素的船员和通讯设备能够弥补当前殖民地基建中最大的漏洞。这能让当地的基础设施至少达到 英仙座星域 文明社会的最低标准。
当你顶着 Skiron 的工人隐晦的注视，再度穿过居住区往回走时，你注意到几个有着轻装备的技师便能轻易地将当地的通讯和基建设施升级到勉强能配得上太空文明的程度。
options:
pk_sentinelLeave:继续走下去。
pk_sentinelLeaveCrewAlt:"我可以留下 100 名船员，作为专家和技师来确保你们的殖民地能继续支撑下去。"

script:
SetEnabled pk_sentinelLeaveCrew false
SetTooltip pk_sentinelLeaveCrewAlt "需要你的$shipOrFleet内拥有 200 名以上的船员。"

AddCommodity crew -100
AdjustRepPerson skiron FRIENDLY 5
$global.leftCrewOnSentinel = true
PK_CMD convertSentinelToColony
FireAll PKSentinelHubOptions
text:
Skiron 停顿了一下，然后半笑着说道 "那就谢谢你了，$playerName舰长。有了他们的帮助，我们可以把这里打造为一个指挥部也能认可的哨站。直到收到指挥部的联络，纪律将引导我们。"

("纪律将引导我们。" 她身后的众人轻声重复道。)

你令你的副官按照安排开工。

你被护送到了一个岩石台地上，你的穿梭机在此等候。Skiron 再度提醒你要回到 霸主 星域，并将 Sentinel 的情况报给指挥部。

就当你即将踏上船时，你在砾石中发现了一块异常明显的骨头碎片。你停下脚步；这应该是一块腓骨，或者一块胫骨。你心怀疑惑：纪律应该会要求荣誉身故的死者被规范地收容。

那，这个是？

不管是什么，这都是很多 星历年 之前的事情了。

你被护送到了一个岩石台地上，你的穿梭机在此等候。Skiron 再度提醒你要回到 霸主 星域，并将 Sentinel 的情况报给'指挥部'。

你刚登陆时在冰冷的碎石中看到的那片碎骨已经不在了。或许这里只是这个单调阴暗的世界上另一处样子相似的小沟吧。

conditions:
$core_pkPlanet score:1000
!$hasMarket
!$global.leftCrewOnSentinel
$global.discoveredSentinel
Highlight  "transmits a weak transponder signal"
text:
$fullName 寒冷刺骨的大地在你面前展开，两极都处于永久的严冬之中。只有天气规律中一些幸运的巧合让个别微小的地区能够勉强适于居住。

第十四战斗群 遗民的村落恰恰位于这么一个地区之中，散发着勉强能够被观测到的微弱无线电波。
options:
pkSentinel_shuttle:坐穿梭机下去
defaultLeave:离开

text: 你降落于一座位于不至于冒犯到对方的距离外的岩石台地之上。Alo Skiron 指挥官带领的一队武装人员再度迎接了你。她做完正式的问候之后便邀请你到殖民地的中心会议厅饮水座谈。

会议厅内部温暖，堆满了军服，武器还有徽标，活像一个纪念 霸主 还是 第十四战斗群 年代的 圣堂

你假装喝了一口那恶心的酵母制饮品。

"你有把我们存活的消息带给指挥部吗？" Skiron努力掩饰着她的不耐烦，问道。 "我们必须要能够上报我们的信息，同时接受指示。"

("使命即是生存; 指挥部即为救赎," 她的副官们在身后低声道。)

id: # Telling a Hegemony admin or military commander about Sentinel

options: pk_tellAboutSentinel:"有一个失落的边缘殖民地，名为 Sentinel，你应该了解一下..." (解释)

script:
AddCommodity credits 50000
AdjustRep hegemony 20
AdjustRepActivePerson 10
$global.toldAboutSentinel = true
PK_CMD convertSentinelToColony
SetPersonPortrait skiron "skiron2"
FireAll PKTellAboutSentinelOutOptions
text:
$post 面带惊讶和担忧地听完了你关于在 Sentinel 生存了超过 100 星历年 并依旧维持着 '纪律' 的船员殖民地的报告。

"你做的是对的。" 听到你留下了一些船员来协助生存艰难的殖民者们，$heOrShe如此说道。"我会立刻向战略指挥部上报此事。我想他们会立刻派出援助和援兵。" $HeOrShe 给了你个战友般的微笑。 "看来着边缘地带还有不少速子阴谋要解决，是吧？舰队有机会好好狩猎一番了。真希望我也能去一趟。"

"好了。" $heOrShe说道，"我需要准备我的报告了，干得漂亮，公民。"

text:

"你做的是对的。" 听到你留下了一些船员来协助生存艰难的殖民者们，还把病弱者带来 核心世界 接受治疗，$heOrShe如此说道。

"把他们卸下来吧，我的副官会做安排。我会立刻向战略指挥部上报此事。我想他们会立刻派出援助和援兵。" $HeOrShe 给了你个战友般的微笑。 "看来着边缘地带还有不少速子阴谋要解决，是吧？舰队有机会好好狩猎一番了。真希望我也能去一趟。"

AddCommodity credits 65000
AdjustRep hegemony 12
AdjustRepActivePerson 6
$global.toldAboutSentinel = true
$global.deliveredInfirmFromSentinel = true
PK_CMD convertSentinelToColony
SetPersonPortrait skiron "skiron2"
FireAll PKTellAboutSentinelOutOptions
text:
$post 面带惊讶和担忧地听完了你关于在 Sentinel 生存了超过 100 星历年 并依旧维持着 '纪律' 的船员殖民地的报告。

"你做的是对的。" 听到你把几个特别病重的殖民者从能力有限的殖民地接了过来，$heOrShe如此说道。

"把他们卸下来吧，我的副官会做安排。我会立刻向战略指挥部上报此事。我想他们会立刻派出援助和援兵。"

"好了。" $heOrShe说道，"我需要准备我的报告了，干得好，公民。"

options: pk_turnInHegemony:"还有一个行星杀手武器的问题..."
pk_tellAboutSentinelAIFleet:"我还发现当初的船队改造了他们的舰队以接受 AI 核心的操控。"

text:
$HeOrShe直起身子回应道："我明白了，多么令人恼火的指控啊。然而即便属实，那也是远在上百个星历年之前的事了。"

$rank 叹了口气："我会把这加进报告书里的，请放心公民，我们会查清此事的。另外，我还建议你将所见所闻留在脑子里。"

稍待片刻，"我很确信彼此都不想把 COMSEC 牵扯进来，想想看那得有多少文书找上门，" $heOrShe试图在切断通讯连接前用一个微笑缓和一下气氛，"下次再见。"

$HeOrShe直起身子回应道。 "我知道了" $heOrShe说到， "这是让人担忧的指控。然而即便属实，那也是远在上百个星历年之前的事了。"

$rank 叹了口气："我会把这加进报告书里的，请放心，辅助军，我们会查清此事的。另外，我还建议你将所见所闻的揣测留在你自己的脑子里。

$HeOrShe停顿片刻，"我很确信彼此都不想把 COMSEC 牵扯进来，想想看那得有多少文书找上门，" $heOrShe试图在切断通讯连接前用一个微笑缓和一下气氛，"下次再见。"

id: # talking to Luddic Pilgrim fleet's captain

options: shrineQuestion:"我想再多了解一下你们的朝圣之旅。"

text: $HeOrShe用充斥着绝望的眼神看着你："求您了，$playerSirOrMadam，可怜可怜我吧。我只是一名身无长物的朝圣者啊。"
$HeOrShe用充斥着绝望的眼神看着你："求您了，$playerSirOrMadam，可怜可怜我吧。我只是一名身无长物的朝圣者啊。"

"我只是个 舰长，不过我自己也朝圣过几次了。" $heOrShe说到。

"我所带领的朝圣者要依 卢德 的教诲去 圣地 冥想并探求 银河之救赎。"

$HeOrShe停顿了一下，然后善意的说道。"所有人都欢迎参与这朝圣之途。"
$HeOrShe做了个简单的祈祷手势 "祝福你，同路之人。我带领朝圣者前往圣地冥想。"
notes: # we can assume if player has commission, they're probably also friendly

options: shrineConv_jobResponse:"运送朝圣者能赚不少钱么？"
shrineConv_shrineQuestResponseA:"我参观过那些 圣地。只是参观。"

notes: # player takes a stance on Luddicism
# player takes a stance on Luddicism

options: shrineConvHostile1Response:"You have fuel and supplies. Surrender them."
shrineConvHostile3Response:"什么？我可不是什么怪物。"
shrineConvOut:"谈 圣地 谈的差不多了。"

text: $HeOrShe点了点头，同意了。

script:
$saidSecular = true
AdjustRepActivePerson FRIENDLY 1
FireBest ShrineFleetConvAttitudeAdjustment
FireAll ShrineFleetConvOptions
text:
"是的，我相信你这是单纯世俗角度的兴趣。"

$HeOrShe 抬起双手安抚道。"自然，我无意冒犯。虽然你不自视为信徒，我还是感谢你对我们信仰的兴趣 —— 而且不论如何，你的兴趣或许能带你更接近 卢德，而这一点让我颇为欣慰。"

"我不是来此布道的，但是我会忠实的回答你的问题。" $HeOrShe笑道。

script:
$saidFaithful = true
AdjustRepActivePerson FRIENDLY 2
FireBest ShrineFleetConvAttitudeAdjustment
FireAll ShrineFleetConvOptions
text: "果真如此？那我以 卢德 之精神欢迎你。" $heOrShe做了一个表示虔诚的手势。 "愿神谕引领你和我所带领之人走上精神进步的光辉之路"

$name面带耐心的笑容，摇了摇头。

"我更愿意把奖励想为灵魂上的回报。很多朝圣者都是普通人；自己无力自费朝圣之人的旅费会由教会负责，又或由更加富裕的教徒的慈善捐赠支持。"

"当然，我们还是时不时会遇到更加习惯...世俗生活的新教徒。他们一般倾向于比我们舰队更加朴素的环境。你或许能够找到这类人在太空佬聚集的酒吧寻求搭载。

"每个圣地都是为了纪念先知卢德教给我们的神圣理想而建设的。每个圣地都对应一个特定的段落、概念，或纪念一个事件。它是... "

$HeOrShe突然停下来，"...嗯，这就说来话长了。住持圣地的神职人员可以完美解释它们的意义，并协助朝圣者将这一意义应用于他们自己的精神旅程。"
"我们前往死亡世界，Killa。"
options: shrineConv_askKilla:"Killa 是座废墟，怎么能是圣地？"

text: "我们要前往 Volturn，尽管那里...情况复杂。"

options: shrineConv_askChico:"Chicomoztoc? But it's a polluted wasteland."
shrineConv_askBeholder:"Doesn't Beholder Station orbit a gas giant?"
shrineConv_askGilead:"Gilead. Isn't that where the Luddic Church is based?"

text: "我们正在前往 Jangala。"
options: shrineConv_askJangala:"位于 Jangala 的圣地？那里的生物毒素怎么办？"

text:
$HeOrShe看上去有些担忧。

"我最后一次听到相关的消息，就是他们为了 '公众安全' 实行了什么 '暂时戒严'。" $heOrShe面带抵触地说道。"Andrada 打算打压我们的信仰。假如他能，他会将其踏平。假如，" $heOrShe 重复道，"他能。"

"对人类来说，是毒素。迟早会是。我的见解是这是教导我们虚心知足的一课，就算我们无法居住在那里，那里依旧能够充满生命。

"我听说那里有些最为极端的信徒甚至愿意不带面具直接接触异星生命。也不用药品，什么都不用。" $HeOrShe看上去即欣慰，又有些反感。

"我是做不到那样的！卢德 慈悲在上，我听说过的那些事..."
$HeOrShe似乎想起了$hisOrHer的职责，$HeOrShe的表情显得更专业 "但那都是闲话，而你知道什么是重点。我们讲到哪里了..."

"啊。" $HeOrShe思索了一下。"我想既然我们身处朋友和信徒之中，我们也能打开天窗说亮话了。"

$HisOrHer的温暖被更加沉重的口气替代。"Killa 是用来纪念所有被那万恶的 行星杀手 所谋杀之人，以及所有因愤怒而起的战争所枉死之人的圣地。"

"那里... 对我们是一个沉重的提醒，一个警示，一个哀悼之地。也是一个太容易被遗忘之地。" $HeOrShe沉默了片刻。
options:
shrineConv_askKillaVisit:"你能告诉我怎样找到那里吗？"
shrineConv_askKillaPK:"告诉我更多关于这个 '行星杀手' 的事情。"
shrineConv_askKillaEnd:继续

text:
"额" $name给了你个奇怪的眼神。"名字已经说的很清楚了：行星杀手。"

"那是个可怖之物，我不愿轻易将其提起。"

"对不起，舰长" $name看上去不太舒服地说道，"那个圣地... 是个神圣之处，而且其设计上就颇为隐秘。我到底只是个舰队指挥官，轮不到由我来指引你走上如此沉重的朝圣之途。 你必须得和负责维护 圣地 的教士们讨论此事。"

"比如去 Gilead，或者 Jangala？" $heOrShe抱歉的补充道。

$HeOrShe思索了片刻，随后用沉重的口气说道。"Killa 是用来纪念所有被那万恶的 行星杀手 所谋杀之人，以及所有因忿怒而起的战争所枉死之人的圣地。"

"那里是.. 对我们是一个沉重的提醒，一个警示，一个哀悼之地。也是一个太容易被遗忘的地方。" $HeOrShe沉默了片刻。
"唔。让我们谈点别的吧。" $heOrShe says.

id: # Luddic Knight conversation after attacking pilgrims

text:
通讯链接嗡嗡着建立了链接。 $TheFactionLong $personRank 厌恶的看向你。

"我面前是一亵渎神圣的和平，袭击手无寸铁朝圣者的恶徒。" $heOrShe怒道。"你有何所图？掠夺他们仅有的资产？" $HeOrShe深深吸了一口气， $hisOrHer的愤怒已经几乎完全耗尽了$hisOrHer的自制力。

"你残忍的投机行为是对我等战士之荣耀的亵渎。我的命令便是找到并摧毁你，但我个人将此看作一位军官和一个卑劣的懦夫之间的决斗。"

"让你的$shipOrFleet准备战斗，舰长。" $heOrShe啧道， "让咱们看看你怎么光明正大地战斗。"

options: academyQuestionStart:"这 'Galatia 学院' 是什么？'"
academyQuestionJob:"学院的运输工作报酬如何？"

text:
$HeOrShe一瞬间看上去有些惊讶，但是很快便反应了过来。"啊，对啊。我们的任务信息已经登入了我们的 应答器 号码之中。"

"Galatia 学院 是 英仙座星域 最为尖端的学术和研究中心。学院不和任何第三方 势力 挂钩，以便所有知识都能被保存，所有新发现都能被共享。"

说完了这么理想化的一段演讲，$HeOrShe看上去有些羞耻。"至少，说是这么说的。政治上的各种往来总是存在的，但学院确实是个想做善事的中立之地。我为能帮他们跑活自豪。"
options:
academyQuestionJob:"学院的运输工作报酬如何？"
academyQuestionWhere:"Galatia 学院 在哪里?"
cutCommLink:告别并切断通讯链接

text: "额。啊。在 Galatia 星系。" $HeOrShe 可敬地避免了瞧不起人的口气来说这段话。 "学院在 Pontus 轨道上。按我说风景非常美丽。不过我也确实喜欢环系统。"
options:
academyQuestionJob:"学院的运输工作报酬如何？"
cutCommLink:告别并切断通讯链接

text: "学院只保有一小队研究舰，尤其是出了 ISS Enki 事件之后。" $heOrShe说到， "所以他们的运输工作都外包给了我这样的自由业个体户。"
options:
academyQuestionPay:"报酬如何？"
academyQuestionEnki:"ISS Enki 发生了什么？"
cutCommLink:告辞并切断通讯链接

text:
"啊。" $hisOrHer的眼神躲避着你，但是却无法找到办法来绕开这个令人不适的话题。

"这是 第二次AI战争 年代的事情了，大概 12，3 星历年 之前。有一支 Galatia 学院 的研究舰队不慎发现了 霸主 在 Tia-Taxet 星系的一个秘密计划。当时 霸主 面临相位船的袭扰，还有 超波 通讯系统的崩坏，更别说战时本来就多疑... ", $heOrShe闭上了眼睛。"结果 霸主 发起了攻击，学院船只无一幸存，损失惨重。倒是有一些生还者，我在 Syrinx 上跟其中一位聊过，他们直到战争结束都关在牢里。"

"这事不常有人提起，至少 霸主 那边是这样的。但就算是 学院 也没有那么积极地索要赔偿... " $HeOrShe声音渐渐低了下去，然后抬头看向你。 "总之，都是过去的事了。"
options:
academyQuestionPay:"所以报酬如何？"
cutCommLink:道别并切断通讯链接。

text:
"哦，够好了，不算一流，不算垫底。我给你提个醒。" $heOrShe眨了眨眼。"真正的好处是你能结交的人脉。每个势力呼风唤雨的大人物都会把他们最聪明的后代送到 Galatia 学院。这时我就能自我介绍，说些 '作为舰长，我会保证你孩子绝对安全。' 之类的话，他们特别受用。"

"然后。" $heOrShe强调道， "你就能从这些大人物和金主那边接活儿了。"
options:
academyQuestionPay1:"聪明，谢谢提点。"
academyQuestionPay2:"这再明显不过了。"
cutCommLink:道别并切断通讯链接

text: "不客气。" $heOrShe看到能传授点宇宙民的经验给你，颇为高兴。"说到这，我想我客套的也差不多了。一路顺风，舰长。"
"你说的是。" $heOrShe翻着白眼说到。"那我猜你也是个明白人了。一路好走，舰长。" $heOrShe刻意用了滚地佬的告别方式说道。

"通讯接通，收到。" $Post $name说道。"我们就是来这见识下当年 Mairaath 的风光样子的缩影。"
OR
"扫描完毕，身份确认。保持距离和航向。"

$post 望向你，打算聊聊天。"看到 Mairaath 这个样子，我心里挺不是滋味。"

"通讯接通，收到。" $Post $name说道。 "我们是跑商的， Mairaath 商路。是的，那里还有值得买卖的东西。 "
OR
"问候收到。" $post 说道。"维持航线，Mairaath 商路还值得跑，就算不值得，我还是会跑。"

options: greetingsAskMairaathGlory:"为什么 Mairaath 的路线有可能不值得走？"

text:
$HeOrShe 看了你很久，目光中的惊奇掩盖了悲伤。

"我想你不是这里人，得有人给你讲讲这事。"

"当年， Mairaath 是 英仙座星域 的奇迹。轨道上有三座巨城，又叫星际城，地面上则是生化 地貌改造 造成的奇迹。"  $hisOrHer的语气现在带上了苦涩，"有些 左径 看不得别人能够不畏黑暗的好好生活，所以... "

"他们把它炸了。" $heOrShe说道，面色僵硬。"那些狂信徒把它给炸了。你要问我，这是这个星域经历过的最为可怖的恐怖袭击。千万人身亡，整个星球的梦想化为灰烬。真正的奇迹是居然有人幸存。" $HeOrShe指向$himOrHerself， "我的祖先活了下来，不知如何做到的。"

"到最后一刻我们都是 Mayasura 人。过了最后一刻，我们还是，哪怕我们世界的死亡也没能把我们杀尽。就算我们拾荒过活，我们也还活着。"

就算 Mairaath 荣光不在。$HeOrShe依旧自豪。
"链接。通讯接通。" $Rank $name 说道。 "我们为了保护神圣的 Gilead ，时刻警惕着。"

options: greetingsAskDefenseGilead:"什么让 Gilead 那么神圣？"

text:
$HeOrShe 眨了眨眼。 "为什么？先知 卢德 是被神谕呼唤到了 英仙座星域 的 Gilead 星球的。Ludd 降临并触摸了 Gilead 的大地，宣布其乃神之馈赠，并号信徒将其变成一个花园世界。作为生命中神圣平衡的活生生的例子，一个朝圣之地。"

"不论是否为信徒。" $heOrShe 真诚地说道，"我们都欢迎你去 Gilead 的圣地亲自看一看。"
"清晰收到，周边一切绿油油，$Post $name 说道。"别担心，$playerSirOrMadam，我们只是来做正经生意的，不会碰 Gilead 一根汗毛！"

options: greetingsAskTouchGilead:"等下，为什么不能碰 Gilead？"

text:
"哦，你别也给我来这一套了。" $heOrShe说道，"我没啥特别的意思。" 

漫长的沉默，随后$heOrShe说道，"啊，你是真的要问啊。嗯，那不是个 卢德圣地嘛？教会把谁能前去，去了干什么事把关可严了。你可不想招惹 卢德骑士团，他们可是连个玩笑和宣战布告都分不清的。"

"我意思就是在他们和他们的世界上，手脚干净些。" $HeOrShe点了点头， "就当免费给你的建议。"

"Sometimes I ponder what my life would be in the Domain - an uncollapsed Domain, that is," $heOrShe says, contemplative. "A glittering sea of living worlds, each filled with history."

"Though I suspect someone who went needling around asking uncomfortable questions might get into a spot of trouble, eh?" $HeOrShe gives an unacademic snort. "I've managed to produce enough of that - trouble, I mean - for myself in the here-and-now. If you don't anger the institutions you're not doing good work, I think."

"Oh 'Infernium', yes yes. It's a bit of Luddic vernacular, refers to antimatter starship fuel. Though what they really mean," and here $heOrShe stresses the word, "is rather more."

"In certain texts the term encompasses all AM applications, or even all high-energy processes. 'The get of Mammon and Belial', one creative firebrand called it. I like that one; I've always enjoyed the dramatic rhetoric of Luddic folk-preaching tradition."

"Now I may be old, but there are older by far. If the records are to be believed - and I do believe, the Hegemony keeps very good records - then the pirate Warlord Kanta was born well before the Collapse. Or shall we call her ex-Domain Armada officer Jorien Kanta?" $HeOrShe looses a wheezing laugh. 

"Oh yes, she had a name like anyone else, once upon a time. One wonders if it's expensive biomods or periodic cryosleep that keeps her going. I'd love to find out..."

"Hmm, history is not all the study of 'great leaders', but one can't help but admire a narrative of glorious victory, hubris, and ignominious end. Philip Andrada, for instance."

$HisOrHer gaze drifts into the past as $heOrShe speaks, "I remember like it was yesterday. He embodied all that was proud and good in the Hegemony. Practically deified on every holo following his defeat of the Warlord Loke. Oh, how we celebrated at that news! It was the vanquishing of chaos itself, the dawn of a new golden age. So it felt, once."

"His turn wounded us," $heOrShe says softly. "It wounded the Hegemony itself, very deeply." $HeOrShe nods to $himOrHerself, drifting back into some old memory.

"I've considered cryosleep. Pay the fee, jump ahead a hundred cycles to see how everything turns out. As a historian, by the stars, it's quite an appeal! On the other hand - yes, yes - I know the statistics. The failure rates are low nowadays... if you find a good vault. But it still scares me. You could just go to sleep and never wake up." 

$HeOrShe laughs darkly, "Though that's every single day, isn't it? Ah, I have too much work to do, anyway..."

"Aliens! Hah. No, there's nothing well documented enough to be considered," $heOrShe stresses the words, "Legitimate History."

"Yes yes, if you want to experience xenolife, visit Jangala and take your pills and quarantine shower."

"But that's simply not what is meant, is it. We want there to be someone else out there like us, someone to talk to, someone to tell us we're not alone, someone to give us answers. Someone who cares. Perhaps we're looking in the wrong place? Or thinking in the wrong way?" $HeOrShe dismisses the thought with the shake of $hisOrHer head. "Eh, but this grows into speculation. Not my trade!"

"We've all heard the stories about the Onslaught battleship, the final weapon that stood against an alien threat." $HeOrShe scoffs, waving a dismissive hand, "As if we live in some milfic holo about brave heroes and vile aliens."

"Grand historical context-breaking contact doesn't work that way, at least in our body of knowledge. It's more confusing; messy and chaotic. It undermines the entire cognitive-ideological basis of society, which is then forced to reform around a great wounding of its very epistemological basis. And always, so many must die to learn these lessons."

$HeOrShe gets a distant look for a moment, then breaks into a sardonic smile. "Not unlike the Collapse eh? Must be aliens." $HeOrShe winks. "For sure."

"Old Earth, mother Terra. From whence we came, long gone. The Luddics aren't completely wrong in their stories. Though, hm, they possess few qualms about 'improving' details to appeal to their quotidian morale framing."

"The historical record is far more complex than that telling, and far more difficult. Far more relatable in the end as well, I believe. Every day we survive by powerful technologies which any one of us barely understands, and which may unleash truly apocalyptic destruction. Mistakes are made, tragedy results; it's only a question of scale."

$HeOrShe considers this for a moment, then begins mumbling a critical response to $hisOrHer own thoughts, "But scale can indeed fundamentally change the quality of phenomena and hence the contextualization of the moral dimension, hmm, quite entirely! Hmm..."

"Though much of the Persean Sector has been effectively freed from the Domain's technology restrictions - without dismissing the Hegemony's best bloody-minded efforts, of course," $heOrShe gives a half shrug to their efficacy, "-this age has not seen any especially great leaps of technological development. Why not? For the Persean League, or Tri-Tachyon among others, the ban is lifted!"

"Perhaps it is that development of highly complex, advanced technologies requires a stable foundation: a large population base with excess theoretical and engineering capacity, a willingness to devote resources to pursuits beyond mere survival. Or war. And yes, war drives innovation - of a sort. But imagine the possibilities if those billions of credits had not been vaporized alongside so many foolish youths... like those I once knew."

$HeOrShe goes very quiet for a moment. "Those old production chips and nanoforges offer a ladder with the middle rungs missing. We fight to reach toward the top, doomed to fall as the step falters..."

"The Human Domain split key industries into separate worlds, although yes, with redundancies - set well apart from one another. If one world which produces hyperdrives tried to leverage their specialization against the Domain, well, what good are they without raw materials? Or AM fuel? Or, indeed, the basic necessities of life and access to markets?"

"How can one rebel when the Domain need only control the local Gate to lay a complete siege? Which one world could possibly stand against the entire Domain?" $HeOrShe gives a grim smirk. "Now we're stuck here, besieged by the Domain. There's no one to accept our surrender but some dead Gates."

"The Galatia Academy? Oh yes, yes, I once attended. And taught there too, if you'll believe it. For quite a few cycles. They figured me as a troublemaker soon enough, but I was slippery. I played the game. Me! Hah, would you believe that?"

$HeOrShe laughs at some old memory. "Made a few enemies too, I did."

"Did you hear who they put in charge of the Academy? Anahita Baird! Can you believe it? The wolf is tending the sheep now, and that's the truth. The Hegemony has no idea what they've done." $HeOrShe cackles, "No idea!"

"With Baikal Daud in the office of High Hegemon, I can't help but wonder at what mark his administration will make on the 'Phoenix of the Persean Sector'. The old guard still dominate the navy - that's the Eventide contingent. Those families go back to the arrival of the 14th, of course. It's not an old aristocracy by any historical standard, but the pattern is established quickly enough given agreeable conditions. Where was I- yes, Daud. Man of the people. Ruffles feathers. Like when he intervened personally in the Sphinx ensigns scandal. Hegemons simply don't do that! But he's a born leader, none can deny it."

"That's what is really going to get him in trouble," $heOrShe says, then goes quiet, lost in thought.

"In my circles- that's historians, mind you, not just old folks hanging around the bar," $heOrShe chuckles at $himOrHerself. "We've made a rule not to argue about Artemisia Sun unless legitimate new information appears. And it never does!" $HeOrShe pauses for a moment, tapping $hisOrHer book. "But you're not a historian, so the rule doesn't apply. Wonderful, you get to hear me out!"

"So: Why was she voted off the board just in time for the crucial military disaster of the Second AI War, then able to sweep back into her office with the credibility of all who opposed her absolutely annihilated? Was it merely a ruthless recovery, or was this a calculated sacrifice of Tri-Tachyon assets in order to consolidate her personal power from the start?" $HeOrShe smiles. "Maybe we can hash this theory all the way through one of these days."

"How we long for some incidental recording of even one of Ludd's supposed speeches or acts. Incredible, is it not, how all evidence of a prophet seems to have disappeared? This, hrm, 'miracle' is of course a point of faith among followers of the Church of Galactic Redemption." 

$HeOrShe raises an eyebrow at you. "It is also, officially, a point of policy for the Hegemony to cooperate with this nonsense in order to appease those Faithful." $HeOrShe furrows $hisOrHer brow in frustration, "As a historian, of course, this vexes me to no end. History as experienced by the common person may be a story society tells itself, and distorted as such. Even still! It must be grounded in fact."

"Of course if I did discover a holovid of Ludd's Trial, some fanatic would try to murder me soon enough for distributing it. Not that I could help myself." $HeOrShe smiles impishly, then considers. "If you do ever find something like that in some old derelict, you'd give me a copy, wouldn't you?"

"You wouldn't believe how much of my work is built upon cargo manifests. I have a former student working on Agreus; they send me copies lifted off scrapped memory cores. The real secrets are wiped, of course, but the story is all there, in the lines of onloaded and offloaded cargo compared against the hull mass calculations used by navigation to say nothing of the hyperdrive. History is written in logistics!"

"Take for instance the sheer quantity of food and supplies that 'disappear' on trade routes skimming the edge of the Core Worlds. Statistical sampling suggests that a significant percent of all economic activity in the Persean Sector is 'off the books', and a significant portion of that goes straight toward those who are called 'pirates' as well as the so-called 'decivilized' populations... to say nothing of undocumented populations within the Core itself."

The historian leans close, "The official population census of the Persean Sector could be off by as much as an order of magnitude. It's simply astounding." $HeOrShe smiles, and shaking $hisOrHer head.

"Ah, like I was just telling those young folks over there," the historian waves $hisOrHer hand toward a small group which seems to be avoiding eye contact, "- after the trials of the Cold Passage, the 14th Battlegroup limped across the Persean frontier to discover a sector dominated by the Warlord Leonis. The joint command of the 14th struck down that cruel reign and were hailed as liberators, laying the groundwork for Admiral Kali Molina to make a declaration of Hegemony over the Domain colonies of the Persean Sector with the Eventide Diktat of cycle 49."

"The untarnished Hegemony of that time was too overshadowed by memories of the Domain to truly appreciate the political capital at the High Hegemon's command. Short-term thinking prevailed in anticipation of Gate reactivation. Indeed," $heOrShe puts on a look of sad understanding, "How could they have known that discontinuity would persist for so long, perhaps forever?"

"Whoever Ludd was, they were not a mere uneducated rabble-rouser. Besides," $heOrShe lowers $hisOrHer voice, "I subscribe to the theory - held by more than a few secular scholars, though quietly, quietly indeed - that Ludd was not one, but many. I would argue that the present format of the Holy Ecumene Council of Archcurates is a reflection of the early Luddic leadership network passed down through history, institutionalized in the early years post-Collapse."

"Heresy, of course. But the truth generally is," $heOrShe says with a smirk.

"The contemporary form of the Church of Galactic Redemption has proven remarkably stable in spite of, or perhaps because of, the chaotic political arrangement of the Persean Sector immediately post-Collapse."

The historian cradles $hisOrHer hands, unconsciously repeating the old motions of lecturing.

"The Holy Ecumene Council of Archcurates rule on matters of canon, authorize and delegate executive functions, and perform certain exclusive sacraments. However they may be censured and even laicized by a supermajority of the Curates-popular! The members holding those more common positions are ratified by local congregations but must be ordained by an Archcurate in good standing."

$HeOrShe sips some tea, then frowns and looks at $hisOrHer cup as if the tea had gone unexpectedly cold. "Of course, it's rather more complicated than just that in practice..."

"There are those among the Church of Galactic Redemption - the Luddics, in popular parlance - who hold that the Knights of Ludd are an aberration at odds with the original Luddic vision of the Church. Doubtless true," the historian raises $hisOrHer eyebrows at this small heresy. "An examination of what are agreed by scholars to be among the more authentic passages of the Book of Ludd suggest that themes of militancy and 'a knighthood of the faith' are likely intended as abstract references to a sort of semi-sacral militant volunteerism which would range in practice from a civic protest movement all the way to, arguably, insurrectionism."

"The practical benefit of a standing militant order during the Post-Collapse chaos and following wars must be admitted, however," $heOrShe leans back in $hisOrHer seat, contemplative. "And the most vocal objectors within the Church proper argue that the Knights err by degree rather than in whole. The less vocal objectors? Well, we may not know their thoughts for many, many cycles indeed. The Knights see to that."

"It is speculated that Admiral Andrada, the self-annointed Supreme Executor of the Sindrian Diktat - or 'Sindrian Mutiny' per the Hegemony viewpoint - is facing a dictator's all-too-common problem of succession. Until now, behind the unified facade of the Diktat, it appears that he has played his major supporters off one another to maintain political stability. Declaring a clear successor would have disrupted this internal balance." 

"And now," the historian speaks slowly, rubbing $hisOrHer chin, "with the cycles' inevitable turn and Andrada in rumored poor health, will he make a surprise announcement to designate an heir? There would be a wave of arrests and, dare I say, executions as those loyal and disloyal to the Executor-apparent are... sorted."

"Or perhaps Andrada has a secret family, or a mind-simulation, or a clone, or some wilder scheme?" $HeOrShe barks a laugh. "Speculation on this point seems to say as much about the speculator as about anything Andrada is thinking. I should ask you for some insight!" $HeOrShe laughs again.

"If Philip Andrada, the self-annointed Supreme Executor of the Sindrian Diktat, were the strategic mastermind he was claimed to be - first by Hegemony propaganda and then his own - then why then did he not simply sweep the Persean Sector in a conquest to rival his greatest vanquished foe, the Warlord Loke?"

"Well!" The historian raises a finger like an orator, then, thinking better of it, lets $hisOrHer hand drop to the table. "Matters abound! Andrada took a portion - but only a portion - of the Hegemony navy in the course of his mutiny. He took possession of the Askonia system and was immediately faced with the catastrophic consequences of the Opis incident, ongoing rebellion, complete lack of logistics, and the pressing need to maintain a credible military force against a vengeful Hegemony. And, indeed, all of this while fulfilling the expectations of key supporters!" 

"The true testament to Andrada's genius may well lie in his scheme not immediately collapsing in upon itself!"

"The culture of transient interstellar starship crew and infrastructure workers - "spacers", if you like - has become particularized in the era post-Collapse. Rather than existing in vast diffusion across the Human Domain as a mere statistical category, impossibly detached and undistinguished, they've been localized to the Persean Sector and now form a critical mass of intra-cultural contact out of which distinct commonalities arise."

$HeOrShe takes a moment to catch $hisOrHer breath before proceeding. "Indeed, the majority of interstellar logistics have shifted from Gate to hyperspace journeys. Spacers bear everyday witness now to the ruins of the Collapse and AI Wars. These journeys are haunted," $heOrShe takes on a jovially grim tone. "Haunted, one might say, by history. Indeed, one might suggest that Spacer culture has become quite superstitious in the last two hundred cycles."

$HeOrShe trails off, letting a breath go, looking upward toward unseen stars. "The great dark filled with death and mystery as never before," $heOrShe says, quoting something.

"Old Mairaath, the center of the old Mayasuran stellar polity, was primed to blossom as a shining beacon of culture and civilization in the Persean Sector, a light to outshine Opis perhaps, once the terraforming came into true fruition."

"Both those lights are extinguished, now," the historian says gloomily. "I suppose they lacked the hard-hearted military-industrial alignment of the Hegemony's Eventide-Chicomoztoc axis, to say nothing of Kazeron and its League. And so on, for the rest of them."

"The worst of us thrive in these violent times, it seems." $HeOrShe seems to realize in the moment who $heOrShe is speaking to and adds, without conviction, "Uh, present company excluded, of course."

"What precisely the Hegemony does with the 'forbidden' AI confiscated by its technological inspectors, particularly during the post-AI Wars crackdowns, is not - yet - a matter of historical record. And unlikely to ever be, if COMSEC has their way," $heOrShe says bitterly. 

"Obviously," $heOrShe continues, "the Hegemony is more conservative in exploitation of AI relative to the Domain at its height. The grumblings of the Luddic population ring loud in any Hegemon's ears, and Baikal Daud knows better than to spark unrest under the present peace-of-compromise."

"Now that said," the historian leans closer, lowering $hisOrHer voice, "The paranoid provide entertaining speculations. One theory tells of secret overminds hidden in far-off planetoids simulating worlds which hold in thrall the minds of billions of bio-suspended human slaves; cruel scenarios playing out in the sick imagination of uncaring AI-gods. Nonsense, of course," $heOrShe smiles reassuringly. "What purpose would such mistreatment serve?"

"Those who awake from cryosleep who were laid to rest in the time of the Domain are perhaps the most lost of all. Many, though not all, imagined they would populate the far end of a rich frontier; they accepted that they would leave behind all they once knew. Now they all find themselves cut loose from all reference, unmoored in history."

"And who is to care for them? Certainly the Luddics suggest the comfort of their religion. Others take up drink or drugs, or nihilistic detachment which too-often spills outward into destruction. Not a few of the most brutal pirates are former sleepers, you know."

"Where records persist, sleepers who are uniquely skilled are sometimes... recruited, drafted - 'kidnapped' is perhaps the word - by parties seeking insight into some old tech or lost secrets." A troubled look crosses $hisOrHer face. "I admit that if I could, I would arrange for the systematic interview of the sleepers. They would prove an excellent resource to our pre-Collapse histories, provided we keep a realistic understanding of the limitations of firsthand sources."

"I find myself with a growing affinity for the developing itinerant spacer culture," $heOrShe gestures to the patrons around you. "They have developed a colorful millieu, worldview, and even a shared mythology."

"Although," $heOrShe leans in, "on a personal level, I cannot but wonder if something of the world itself has changed since the Collapse. Has hyperspace become more chaotic, mysterious; inhabited, almost, by alien phenomena? Or was it simply unobserved, or unreported before? Or were the reports suppressed? Or was there simply not enough intra-spacer contact to reinforce their observations - or shall we put it, for the skeptical -  these shared narrative projections?"

"I am a mere historian and, now," $heOrShe smiles sadly, "I am bereft of the corrective presence of my colleagues in the Academy. I both fear and admit that my documentation efforts might appear to drift toward dilettantism."

"The mind reels at the loss of the Collapse," $heOrShe says. "Set aside even the Domain for a moment, with its population inconceivable to our barely-civilized human brains. Just the fringe world of the Persean Sector witnessed untold death as the thin thread of logistics from the Core, and the Domain itself, was cut. Food, life support, medicines, essential machinery - bled out, spilled into space to become so much debris..."

The historian stares off into a corner, $hisOrHer eyes darkened, $hisOrHer attention become lost in the imagined scene of past horror.

"Ah, the tragedy of Opis. The sheer scale of loss is incomprehensible to the mind. To this day there are those who fight and kill over the finer points of whose fault it was. I have my position, but that argument over-dominates the story of the Opisean polity itself. Why should those countless dead be defined by their murderer? I find that the beginning of a story is necessary to illuminate the end, don't you agree?"

$HeOrShe doesn't wait for an answer, but begins to lecture. "Opis was a center of population, of art and commerce. Not heavy industry as-such, however - that they exported to Sindria; and agriculture, to Volturn. Out of sight, out of mind. The rulers of the Chartery of Opis grew to see little need in appeasing any but their local patronage networks. Wealth flowed to the center, where influence coagulated; the edges were forgotten."

"Was it once again the sin of the Domain re-enacted on a smaller stage?" $HeOrShe raises $hisOrHer eyebrows.

"This?" $HeOrShe pats the paper book $heOrShe keeps close, and consults often. "It is... something of an affectation fitting with my self-image."

"There are independent high-tech manufacturers of such objects which range far from traditional papermaking. The integrated digital interface paper-analogs are impressively functional, but my own notebooks? I purchase them from a Luddic craft guild on Tartessus. Indeed, it is mostly composed of dead cellulose."

"I do produce digital backups," $heOrShe admits. "It is not in keeping with full faith in the spirit of the material, but the archivist and researcher in me cannot abide the risk of losing my notes."

text:
As soon as you step into the light, faces turn toward you and a particularly burly patron stands and stares directly at you.

You're still mid-threat assessment when the cheers break out. "Captain $playerName!" someone shouts, then spills half of a mug of something as their companions raise their arms.

It appears as though you have some admirers.
options:
barHighRepEvent0join:Join them for a round and bask in adulation 
barHighRepEvent0calm:Graciously calm them down
barHighRepEvent0nod:Sternly nod an acknowledgement and get on with your business
barHighRepEvent0leave:This is altogether too much. Leave immediately.

text: You join the crew at the table to their uproarious delight, patrons shoving over to make room.
options:
barHighRepEventSpeech0:The stage is yours, why not use it? Give a speech!
barHighRepEventHumble1:Keep it humble and low-key

text:
You leap up onto a table and are handed a drink, which you raise high to a new round of cheers.

"Speech, speech!" the crowd chants, and you make a show of reluctance before giving in to their demands.
options:
barHRE_speechA:Focus on the local VIPs and tell some flattering anecdotes
barHRE_speechB:Compliment the crowd and make a connection with the crews
barHRE_speechC:You're the star! Talk about yourself

text:
You share a few flattering quips and a story about some prominent local officials, earning quiet, cheers, or laughter at the appropriate moments.

Some of the stories might even be true. Or not. What's important is the connections you're making - or pretending you already made - with the local power-players.

You share a few flattering quips and a story about some prominent local officials, earning quiet, cheers, or laughter at the appropriate moments.

You shift the monologue toward a light-hearted review of each of the Luddic shrines you visited, earning tense laughter, but you manage to turn what at first appeared to be subversive implications into a heartfelt conclusion which results in earnest applause from spacer and Faithful alike.

Some of the stories might even be true. Or not. What's important is the connections you're making - or pretending you already made - with the local power-players.

You share a few flattering quips and a story about some prominent local officials, earning quiet, cheers, or laughter at the appropriate moments.

You transition into an anecdote about drinking tea with Brother Livewell Cotton and the bar goes quiet indeed - one particular spacer at the front goes pale and makes to look for the closest exit. You pivot, reassuring the spacer with the finer points of tea etiquette, prompting laughter and earning the fearful spacer good-natured ribbing from their drinking companions. 

Some of the stories might even be true. Or not. What's important is the connections you're making - or pretending you already made - with the local power-players.

You share a few flattering quips and a story about some prominent local Tri-Tachyon figures, earning moments of quiet, cheers, or laughter at the appropriate moments. A joke suggesting that Artemisia Sun is an AI core lands particularly well with the crowd despite earning you a deadly look from a finely-dressed executive sitting alone near the back of the room.  

Some of the stories might even be true. Or not. What's important is the connections you're making - or pretending you already made - with the local power-players.

You share a few flattering quips and a story about some prominent gens and officials, earning quiet, cheers, or laughter at the appropriate moments.

Your impression of Reynard Hannon's accent draws particular divisions between his supporters and detractors in the crowd, but you manage to defuse the tension with a well-timed joke, transforming scowls into self-deprecating smiles.

Some of the stories might even be true. Or not. What's important is the connections you're making - or pretending you already made - with the local power-players.

You share a few flattering quips and a story about some prominent local Hegemony officials, earning quiet, cheers, or laughter at the appropriate moments. A pack of cadets in the corner is especially taken with an aside about meeting High Hegemon Daud.

Some of the stories might even be true. Or not. What's important is the connections you're making - or pretending you already made - with the local power-players.

You share a few off-color quips and a story involving some of the more prominent local pirates, earning quiet or cheers at the appropriate moments.

A hush falls over the bar as you recall your meeting with Kanta herself; you manage to break the tension with an unflattering aside about her 'doctor', Cydonia, prompting laughter and pounding of tables.

Some of the stories might even be true. Or not. What's important is the connections you're making - or pretending you already made - with the local power-players.

You speak about the hard-working spacers that make everything you've done possible, sharing a story of daring, danger, and victory. Moments of quiet, cheers, or laughter come at the appropriate moments as you connect the experiences of your crew with the individuals at the tables around you.

Some time later, in a quiet corner, the bartender hands you a tall glass of cool water with a nod.

Your personnel officer pings your datapad with a surprised message about a number of enthusiastic, and slightly drunk, spacers choosing to sign on to your $shipOrFleet while waiving the usual contract signing bonus.

You start slow, and quiet, forcing the crowd to quiet themselves and one another to hear you.

Having caught their attention, you lay it on about the dangers and trials you have faced - how is it possible you're here, alive, to tell the tale? Through laughter, cheers, and hushed moments you speak of your deeds to the rapt audience and, in a roaring conclusion, somehow connect it all to the greater glory of $theMarketFaction, to applause from the entire bar. 

Somehow you're the hero of the day, though only a handful here knew it when you first walked in.

Having caught their attention, you lay it on about the dangers and trials you have faced - how is it possible you're here, alive, to tell the tale? Through laughter, cheers, and hushed moments you speak of your deeds to the rapt audience and, in a roaring conclusion, somehow connect it all to the proudly independent polities and spacers, to applause from the entire bar. 

Somehow you're the hero of the day, though only a handful here knew it when you first walked in.

You start slow, and quiet, forcing the crowd to quiet themselves and one another to hear you.

Having caught their attention, you lay it on about the dangers and trials you have faced - how is it possible you're here, alive, to tell the tale? Through laughter, cheers, and hushed moments you speak of your deeds to the rapt audience and, in a roaring conclusion, somehow connect it all to the fierce and free pirates of the Persean Sector, to applause from the entire bar. 

Somehow you're the hero of the day, though only a handful here knew it when you first walked in.

You quietly inquire about what the group is drinking to, setting off laughter and good cheer. You're handed a drink, and as you sip, hear several versions of your latest exploits, each more unlikely than the last. 

You do your best to correct the worst exaggerations, but the consensus has clearly formed that you're playing it down.

With the round complete, you make your apologies to much good-natured booing, and tactfully make for a dark corner to recover your thoughts and take in the bar- the bartender, with a nod, ensures you have a tall glass of cold water at hand.

Refreshed, and having quieted things down, you have a chance at last to look around.

Smiling, you try to calm this table. Unfortunately, this just feeds their enthusiasm. Crews sitting at more tables turn to look, patrons whispering to one another and pointing, and others raising their voices to call out.

It's going to be very difficult to find any contacts here with all this attention.
options:
barHighRepEvent0join:Might as well join them for a round
barHighRepEvent0leave:This is too much; wave politely as you leave

text:
You give a stern nod, the very face of stoicism.

Your example triggers a rush of somewhat tipsy salutes and over-exuberant return nods. More drink is spilled in this process, but at least they've quieted down.

You give a sedate wave of acknowledgement, turn right around, and walk out of the bar.

The cheers and shouts, only growing louder, are muffled as you step into the outside corridor.
notes: # it's just going to happen again, ha-ha

text:
A patron does a double-take, and with recognition comes a look of intense hatred.

"You!" the shout cuts through the clatter and noise of the bar like a shot. The burly spacer stands, and readies a meaty fist...

Only to be thrown back onto a table with a smash of glassware by one of your bodyguards - generally discrete, but paid well to take initiative at times like these.

The chaos begins to spread outward, crew and locals alike staring, and those drunkest and angriest standing.

You hear your name spoken like a curse, and a makeshift missile shatters on the support column behind you.

Your bodyguards form a human wall to cover your path toward the exit. Stumbling outside, you can hear the alarms which signal the rapid approach of local MuniSec. There'll be no quiet business done in this bar for the shift, that much is clear.

The chaos spreads outward, crew and locals alike staring, and those drunkest and angriest standing. One pulls a knife, which prompts a pirate three tables down to draw a gun, at which point your instinct to find cover kicks in.

You hear your name shouted like a curse, and an already broken vidscreen on the support column behind you explodes into burning plastic fragments, the soft-round from a boarding pistol putting it well out of its misery.

Your bodyguards respond with controlled bursts from energy weapons set to low-power, giving cover to your withdrawal. Smoke, screams, and flashes of discharge fill the bar. Stumbling outside, you see passers-by clearing out as fast as they can. A noodle stand cook gives you a frightened look as they duck behind armored shutters. There'll be no quiet business done in this bar for the shift, that much is clear.

The chaos spreads outward, crew and locals alike staring, and those drunkest - clearly, this bar doesn't only serve tea and small-beer - and angriest standing.

You hear your name called like a curse, and a makeshift missile smashes against a samovar behind you. It tips, slowly, and falls to the ground with a crash. A small wave of hot tea washes over your boots, and a cloud of steam envelopes you.

Your bodyguards form a human wall to cover your path toward the exit. Stumbling outside, you can hear the bells which signal the rapid approach of Path anti-vice enforcers. There'll be no quiet business done in this bar for the rest of the shift, that much is clear.

The chaos begins to spread outward, crew and locals alike staring, and those drunkest and angriest standing.

You hear your name spoken like a curse, and a makeshift missile shatters on the support column behind you. A pack of cadets rushes the exit, eager to avoid a potential military discipline for involvement in a bar brawl.

Your bodyguards form a human wall to cover your withdrawal. Stumbling outside, you hear the buzz of riot control drones which signals the rapid approach of gendarmerie. There'll be no quiet business done in this bar for the rest of the shift, that much is clear.

The chaos begins to spread outward, crew and locals alike staring, and those drunkest and angriest standing. A couple executives in the back roll their eyes and activate a privacy field as their bodyguards step out of the shadows to protect their small pocket of peace.

You hear your name shouted like a curse, and a makeshift missile shatters on the support column behind you, cracking a vidpanel into fractal nonsense.

Your bodyguards form a human shield to cover your path to the exit. Stumbling into the corridor outside, you can hear alarms and the buzz of surveillance drones which signal the rapid approach of one or another of the corpo security franchises. There'll be no quiet business done in this bar for the shift, that much is clear.

The chaos spreads outward, crew and locals alike staring, and those drunkest - clearly, this bar doesn't only serve tea and small-beer - and angriest standing.

You hear your name called like a curse, and a makeshift missile smashes against a samovar behind you. It tips, slowly, and falls to the ground with a crash. A small wave of hot tea washes over your boots, and a cloud of steam envelopes you.

Your bodyguards form a human wall to cover your path toward the exit. Stumbling outside, you can hear the ringing of alarm bells which signal the rapid approach of the local MuniSec squad led by a Knight of Ludd. There'll be no quiet business done in this bar for the rest of the shift, that much is clear.

text:
A server appears by your side, a glass of what looks exactly like your favorite drink on a silver tray.

"Compliments of the house."
options:
barOwnColFreeDrink0A:"Um. Thank you."
barOwnColFreeDrink0B:Take the drink
barOwnColFreeDrink0C:"Don't I own 'the house'?"
barOwnColFreeDrink0E:"No thanks. I'm, uh, not thirsty."

text: The server nods and politely disappears. A sip reveals that it is perfectly to your taste.
You take the drink and the server politely disappears. A sip reveals that it is perfectly to your taste.
"Technically yes, $playerSirOrMadam, though your organization leases to the proprietor. Who, by the way, extends their compliments."
options:
barOwnColFreeDrink0A:"Thank you."
barOwnColFreeDrink0B:Take the drink
barOwnColFreeDrink0D:"I wish to pay like any other customer. I insist."
barOwnColFreeDrink0E:"No thanks. I'm, uh, not thirsty."

text:
"Of course, $playerSirOrMadam. I'll see that the price of the drink is subtracted from the facility fees."

With that, the server politely disappears. You examine the drink you just bought, then take a sip. It is, in a word, perfect.
The server nods and politely disappears.

text:
茶杯的叮当声突然被一阵碰撞和一声大喊所覆盖。

"恶魔！摩洛克的仆人，玛门的追随者！" 一个头发凌乱、胡子拉碴的人跳到桌子上举起手枪对着你，"我将循修业之径！我将以卢德之锤将你 ——"

一串沉闷的枪响表明你的警卫们进行了消声低穿透力射击，刺客就像一个破布娃娃一样应声倒下。

他身后的茶炊被流弹打凹了下去，茶水潺潺而出，漏到了桌子上逐渐绽开的血泊里。

地方安全部控制住了你和你的警卫，以及几位目击者，直到一位中阶卢德骑士能对情况进行裁定。正当防卫的事实显而易见，目击者对其所见所闻宣以圣誓，并且你的自卫武器许可也都真实有效。

"一位被引入歧途的孩子" 当这名未遂的刺客被朴实无华的裹尸布裹起带走之后，骑士哀叹道。人们的目光随之转向了你，"你的傲慢播下了愤怒，最终收获了这血腥的结果。"

在一段突兀的沉默后他们说："你和你的人；现在走吧。这里发生的事已经了结了。"

"...我如此祈祷，"在你转身离开时骑士低声说道
